Welcome to Polymathic Being a place to explore counterintuitive insights across multiple domains These essays explore common topics from different perspectives and disciplines to uncover unique insights and solutions Today s topic looks straight into the diet of Veganism and finds some uncomfortable truths We ll look at how natural it is whether it can be achieved without first world technology and what it means globally Buckle in for an adventure Intro Veganism is pretty simple You eat nothing that has animal protein of any nature some even include honey in that mix It s a diet that also attracts a lot of very opinionated and passionate people It s one that quickly falls into the psychology of religion in a great many conversations That said I don t intend to debunk the diet or convince anyone to get off it My goal for today s investigation is to contextualize it To that end three things are required for veganism You cannot be vegan off of whole foods alone You must rely on globalization as regional plants do not have the nutritional variety to support veganism You require advanced chemistry industrial laboratories and ultra processing to get all of the required nutrients As such you couldn t have been a vegan except in the last fifty years of human history Simply put it s not how our bodies evolved to ingest and process nutrients This isn t a deal breaker for veganism it s just a contextualization since most people aren t aware of these three facts Let s break them down one by one Whole Foods Plant life is not nutritionally dense This is true in general but even our most nutritionally dense whole foods have often been bred over thousands of years to achieve that density Moreover plants lack the concentration of fats and protein we need as humans This is why vegans must supplement their diets with highly concentrated pea protein and exotic plant fats like coconut and avocado oil Most critically there s an essential vitamin B that humans need which you cannot get from plants or fungi It has to be synthetically produced and fortified into a vegan diet An issue is that synthetic B isn t taken up by the body as well as B from animal protein How essential is B for your health Well just about everything from your brain to nerves to energy production to DNA requires it The National Institutes for Health describes it like this Vitamin B is a nutrient that helps keep your body s blood and nerve cells healthy and helps make DNA the genetic material in all of your cells Vitamin B also helps prevent megaloblastic anemia a blood condition that makes people tired and weak A counterargument is that there are many animals like cows koalas and gorillas that eat only plants However they eat constantly around hours a day and their bodies have a metabolism to process it The koala for example is sluggish because eucalyptus leaves are full of toxins and they ve evolved to process them Cows are more interesting They re actually chemical plants fermenting grass with bacteria and then digesting the dead bacteria into the necessary fats protein and nutrients and not from the grass Lastly that gorilla eats over pounds of food daily and has a vast gut track with bacteria that ferment cellulose into short chain fatty acids Simply put humans cannot ingest enough nutrients amongst the rest of the calories from whole food plant material to maintain a healthy diet without supplements Globalized Food Chain Compounding the whole foods issue is that without our highly advanced global food chain even the number of whole food materials available would be greatly diminished Remember those coconuts and avocados They ve only recently become available in the quantities needed for a vegan diet Fifty years ago they were a novelty even thirty years ago they were hard to find fresh Image by Markus Kammermann from PixabayThe issue is that plant life is highly regional and specified Prior to the Columbian Exchange staples like potatoes peppers tomatoes squash pumpkins and more wouldn t have been known to Europeans Likewise soybeans and their subsequent fermented derivatives like tofu were limited to Asia Native Americans didn t have legumes like peas which comprise much of the protein and fats in vegan diets Considering the global variety of foods required to balance a vegan diet it was impossible to achieve enough nutritional diversity even fifty years ago let alone for it to be a natural alternative for human evolution Regional food is not diverse enough for a healthy vegan diet and requires a global supply chain Ultra Processing This last issue is the solution to the first two Because we lack the nutritional density within whole foods and need to process and collect plant material worldwide we rely on advanced processing technologies extraction techniques and laboratories to synthesize supplements Even natural foods and plants often contain toxins that require processing Cassava is a great example that can cause malnutrition and paralysis if not rendered properly Corn maize is another example where the failure to nixtamalize corn results in pellagra a crippling disease Even the ubiquitous cucumber has been bred to remove the toxins from their skins over the centuries Image by Chokniti Khongchum from PixabayThe next step of processing is often through concentration Seed oils come to mind here where plants like corn rapeseed grape seeds and others are processed into concentrations that you couldn t physically ingest consuming the whole seed Rapeseed Canola Oil is especially egregious with solvent extraction processes using hexane then refining bleaching and deodorizing steps to produce the final product Sometimes the processing of vegan food is straight out of a laboratory where they re creating something that just doesn t exist in nature Let s look at the Impossible Burger I think it gets the name Impossible as a function of how hard it is to find out how they make it I started on their website and was presented with a lot of nice hand waving about the process They do admit to ultra processing and using genetically modified ingredients but this is all cloaked in the obfuscation of reality The ingredient list starts off innocuously enough Water Soy Protein Concentrate Coconut Oil Sunflower Oil Natural Flavors and or less of many vitamins and starches Their main laboratory breakthrough is deriving heme from soybeans to mimic the blood feel of a real burger this is where it gets more complicated Impossible Foods produces heme via fermentation in large batches After fermentation the protein is separated from the yeast and fermentation This separation requires clean water to isolate target heme before being used as the key ingredient in the Impossible Burger The Impossible Burger also uses genetically engineered soy to produce its heme Let s look a bit more closely at the production of heme Extract DNA from the root nodules of soy plants where heme is produced Insert the DNA into genetically engineered yeast cells Ferment the yeast to grow the volume for harvest Isolate the soy leghemoglobin from the yeast Then add the soy leghemoglobin to give them a meaty flavor I m not trying to scare you with the idea of chemicals I ve seen enough fear mongering around misunderstandings that everything is a chemical and yes everything is processed to a point I m sure we all remember the Dihydrogen Monoxide parody over the years My point is merely to show that Vegan food specifically requires exceptionally high tech and precise laboratory conditions to ensure the majority of the nutrients vegans eat Even if vegans don t spend all their time trying to make their vegetables taste like meat and cheese their diet still requires ultra processing to achieve the required nutrition balance The regular use of nutritional yeast requires advanced processing equal to the Impossible Burger to fortify the proper nutrients Wrapping it Together My main complaint about veganism is that it is not how we evolved We also could not have eaten a healthy vegan diet just years ago as we didn t have the global supply chain and industrial processing capabilities that we have today The other challenge is that unless you live in an advanced technology culture like we enjoy in the First World your ability to source a vegan diet is severely limited To think about this another way if you live in a third world country or a tribal culture you literally cannot be vegan for the very reasons we ve explored You cannot be vegan off of whole foods alone You must rely on globalization as regional plants do not have the nutritional variety to support veganism You require advanced chemistry industrial laboratories and ultra processing to get all of the required nutrients However if you re willing to accept these points and feel that the vegan diet is a step in the right direction for humans that s still a viable decision The challenge remains that it s a difficult diet to sustain and we haven t developed the advanced genetic engineering processing and synthesis to make it healthy Our bodies also haven t adapted to consuming concentrated plant material in the quantities required Another thing to consider is that I haven t been able to find a healthy vegan who has been on the diet for over years It s a common question I ask vegans and it s never been answered Adding to this issue are two quick examples A woman I know on the vegan diet was so anemic she had to go to the hospital for regular blood infusions Ironically donated by healthy humans who ate meat Fellow Substacker recently shared how growing up on a vegan diet likely caused lifetime pain and emergency surgery this past year He writes about his experience in Healthy Living Can Be Deadly Perhaps we can refine our nutritional processing to outperform whole plant and meat nutrition but we aren t there yet It s something to pay attention to as we advance and adapt Still we must also consider that evolution has developed humans to use our resources efficiently In fact our exceptionally large brains likely developed because we started to consume highly energy dense animal protein So let s continue to use that big brain of ours and look hard at how veganism is a first world luxury supported by advanced processing and globalization What are your experiences with veganism Drop a comment below Did you enjoy this post If so please hit the button above or below This will help more people discover Substacks like this one which is great Also please share here or in your network to help us grow Share Polymathic Being is a reader supported publication Becoming a paid member keeps these essays open for everyone Hurry and grab off an annual subscription That s a year or a month It s just an essay and makes a big difference Get off forever Further Reading from Authors I AppreciateI highly recommend the following Substacks for their great content and complementary explorations of topics that Polymathic Being shares by All around great daily essays by Insightful Life Tips and Tricks by AI tips for Thinking and Writing by Integrating AI into education by Computer Science for Everyone of The Vegan s Voice is a great example of evangelism of veganism with no critical thinking or facts He s also a great example of cognitive dissonance as any critique results in a deflection or changing the subject He pivots faster than a politician Dr Berg Blog Vitamin B Methylcobalamin vs Cyanocobalamin It s so essential that the body stores years worth just in case This is why many vegans don t notice health issues immediatly and why there s a major drop of practicing vegans after years when the nuerological health issues from B deficiency start to kick in https www nhs uk conditions vitamin b or folate deficiency anaemia causes NIH Office of Dietary Supplements Vitamin B Fact Sheet Accessed Moran John Tropical Dairy Farming Feeding Management for Small Dairy Farmers in the Humid Tropics p Landlinks Press This is one reason why Millenials are known for Avacado Toast It s a luxury good that wasn t available when they were kids and was a novelty as a young adult Bokundabi G Haskins L Horwood C Kuwa C Mutombo PB John VM Mapatano MA Banea JP When knowledge is not enough barriers to recommended cassava processing in resource constrained Kwango Democratic Republic of Congo J Public Health Afr Apr doi jphia PMID PMCID PMC MedlinePlus Encyclopedia Pellegra Accessed Saleem M Ahmad N Characterization of canola oil extracted by different methods using fluorescence spectroscopy PLoS One Dec e Design Life Cycle Website Impossible Burger Accyessed John A Cutting H M Schulman The site of heme synthesis in soybean root nodules Biochimica et Biophysica Acta BBA General Subjects Volume Issue Pages ISSN https doi org American Society for Microbiology The Microbial Reasons Why the Impossible Burger Tastes So Good May Accessed Center for Food Safety Our Beef with the GMO Impossible Burger June Impossible Burger FAQ How Do You Make Heme Accessed Wikipedia Heme Accessed Some have suggested Jainism as an example of a Vegan culture but they re actually mostly vegetarian and even the vegans eat milk products during religious ceremonies They re lacto vegitaeians Charukesi Ramadurai Are Jains the original vegans BBC January Corydon Ireland Eating meat led to smaller stomachs bigger brains The Harvard Gazette April

Quick link to my donations page click here Wonderful Thanks for stopping by my blog I ve done all my actual ultras as opposed to my virtual ones through https www actionchallenge comThey are a wonderful company who cannot do too much for you Highly recommended And I shall be doing events with them this year The London Winter Walk at the end of January accompanied by my two granddaughters and one of their boyfriends Easter Challenge the Thames Path Challenge continuous and the Chiltern in September also in September Here I try and detail all my ultra adventures don t always succeed as I m not the most disciplined bloke in the world both for my own amusement and for anyone who is interested I do ultra marathons for two reasons one because they re bloody good fun and more importantly they are also a means of fundraising for charities which are dear to my heart and benefit the animals I appreciate that times are hard but these are also difficult times for charities as I m sure you ll appreciate Through my ultras I m fundraising for Viva who have been very active rescuing animals from Ukraine and have an animal sanctuary in Poland They also do sterling work exposing the horrors of animal abuse in farms and slaughterhouses Here s a link for anyone who is in a position to donate Wonderful whose services are completely free Many many thanks for the awesome support my efforts are receiving And the animals thank you also If you have any trouble with this link please email me at paulwyoud at gmail com I have several people to whom I look for inspiration and I found most of these on Rich Roll s podcast Rich Roll himself of course is one of my heroes being a vegan ultra runner and ironman extraordinaire Through his podcasts I ve been introduced to a whole range of endurance athletes and positive thinkers David Goggins and Fiona Oakes stand out two of the most inspirational athletes around today In September I faced my biggest challenge yet k continuous along the Thames path from Putney Bridge to Henley My friends Iain and Jo and myself rose early and met in the foyer of our hotel at for the taxi timed at We arrived at the start just before intending to join the first wave at am However the queue for the baggage forwarding was huge and we missed the cutoff time of so we had to wait for the nd wave at Early morning by the Thames is quite special especially on a bright sunny morning with lots of runners dog walkers etc My initial goal for this challenge was to beat the k I achieved years ago when I had to pull out at k after tripping up on a malignant root The first k was pretty uneventful but the views were amazing We did this in about hours Leaving the halfway mark in the gathering dusk Jo and Iain took on the responsibility of guiding me safely along We were warned at the k briefing of the haphazard appearance of dangerous roots right through the second So Iain took the lead followed by Jo and one or the other would announce the presence of danger All the time I had my head bowed looking at the circle of light cast by my head torch When I heard Jo call out Root I would immediately be super cautious So my head was permanently lowered which may help to explain what happened later Sometime early in the morning after the rest stop at k I began to hallucinate I began to be conscious of someone walking beside me but when I looked round there was no one there Later this became a guy with a female on the far side of him This was a constant from now on Then although we were walking on level ground my senses told me we were going downhlll so I started to speed up as imagined gravity took hold So I kept closing up on Jo who kept telling me to slow down But my acceleration was involuntary This went on for km after km always imagining myself going downhill and telling myself to slow down over and over Slow two three four slow two three four But it didn t do any good I still tried to go faster with my two companions alongside me All the while Jo was still calling out Root And I d try to take notice Eventually around k down I went face first into the path this was about ish on the Sunday morning Immediately I was surrounded by love Jo and Iain my two companions came to my aid and also a young trek master Aisling appeared and took charge She got hold of the chief medic at the next rest stop who asked to speak to me He asked if I could sit up so I said I d try and another contestant Natalie Padder I now know sat down on the trail and offered her knees for me to lean up against I was asked if I could stand and a guy I only know as Rich came to help and offered his strong left arm for me to hang on to He was a Welshman with a lovely sense of humour I m so grateful to these two especially who had no thought of their own progress but just wanted to help Oh and thanks to everyone who came past whilst this was going on and stopped to ask if there was anything they could do Then Trek master Martin came by and with his help I managed to walk back about metres to where the road came close to the trail It wasn t long before Driver Steve turned up in a mini bus and I was ferried over to rest stop There I was eventually seen by a medic Kyle who after a series of tests released me in to the care of my son who had driven up to collect me Iain brought me a finishers medal and a T shirt So that was the end of my k continuous dream I ve since promised my very tolerant wife Teresa that I wouldn t attempt another one I ve given it two goes and not made it so I ll probably stick to k distances in future Talking of which I ve signed up to the Bath in March so I m training for this most days averaging k per week I covered km in and I hope to improve on that on Earlier I mentioned the film I could never go vegan in which I m featured climbing Dunkery Beacon You can watch it now on Apple TV or Prime Video With a combination of virtual and actual ultras I m on track to complete my goal of ultras by my th birthday when the still level trail was formed of a compacted stone and earth a larger rock stood proud I hit it and went down full length on the path Nothing major but I had a large contusion on my forehead and a few other cuts and scrapes Here I want to give a huge shoutout to several people firstly Jo and Iain who were absolutely gutted Jo went into shock for a little while and had to sit down Ashling the Trek Master was quickly on the scene and contacted I assume the Control Room I spoke to the Chief Medical Officer who asked me a lot of questions I think I passed because the decision was made to send the mini bus to collect me rather than an ambulance which had been mentioned In the meantime Natalie sat down on the trail and offered her knees to lean back on as I eventually managed to sit up Then a lovely Welsh guy Rich appeared and gave me a strong arm for support as I stood up Then Trek Master Martin appeared and repeated that strong arm guiding me back m to where there was road access Driver Steve helped me into the bus and then across to the Medical Tent where I was seen by Kyle who asked me a lot of tests to determine my mental and physical acuity Once again I passed and was released into the care of my son who d driven up to collect me I got home I think around am and collapsed into bed More to come but I just need to reassure everyone that I m merely achy and stiff and I m in very good spirits And in the meantime please take time out to admire this shiner I mean look at that gorgeous colour Here it is days after the event and I ve not properly thanked everyone who helped me after my fall and those who offered help as well I got to k which is k more than the last time when a malignant root was to blame for my fall and subsequent withdrawal This time it was a rock I hit and down I went One of my sayings is you re never too old to have adventures and adventures have their downs and ups of course Without my fall I may never have met the young trek master Natalie Rich Steve and Kyle and all the others who cared for me And while most contestants go away with just the one trophy I came away with three as the accompanying pic shows I m already planning next year s events which I ve promised my wife won t include any k ones But there s plenty on the calendar for me to relish poring over So see you on the trail This still needs some editing th August God I m hopeless can t believe I haven t updated since the beginning of the year Now I m hoping to do the Thames Path Challenge mid September and the Chiltern at the end of that month nd August Signed up for a k walk along the NSW coastline Then in July I entered the Rocky Mountain Virtual Challenge once again with Conqueror k over the Rockies which I finished on the th July I finished the Land s End to John O Groat virtual in early June took me days Then in April I teamed up with Iain and Jo to do the Easter Walk which was a k loop around Windsor I posted this on Facebook on the th January Winter Walk first event of the yearI had targets with this the first was to have a fun day out with my granddaughters and one of their boyfriends the second was to turn them on to the Action Challenge experience in the hope they will want some more And I succeeded with both They all thoroughly enjoyed the experience even though one of the GDs had done no training whatsoever We completed the West Loop in then had a very tasty veggie chilli and repaired to a nearby pub to relive and savour the whole day Thanks Action Challenge don t know how you managed it but the weather was just perfect Can you do that with all your Challenges please December Well my health problems didn t end with the cellulitis no sooner had I recovered from that than I came down with my first dose of Covid Thanks to my plant based nutrition I wasn t badly affected in fact I ve had far worse colds but of course I had to stay away from other people So I ended up with just the one So my illnesses in the summer blew a big hole in my virtual trip to John O Groats hope to finish this round about May Monday th September Now it s a month later and I m still not right The ankle is still slightly swollen and there s still a patch of red by the ankle bone The skin of the whole area from the knee down to the ankle is dry and peeling I saw the doc on Thursday who prescribed a moisturising cream and recommended I wear flight socks and I m to keep my leg elevated as much as I can With my next ultra only days away I ve taken the decision to defer it again until next year I did think of just doing the k loop around Henley but it s a lot of faff and quite some expense just for a k walk So I ll be concentrating just on my virtual ultras for the foreseeable More on that subject later I m getting out for a minute most days but the most I ve done in the day is about k Friday th August Well my proposed ultra didn t happen after all Two days before the event I came down with a fever On the Thursday morning I had begun to experience a general feeling of unwellness and retired to my bed later that day I had a high temperature and an hour long bout of violent uncontrollable shivering When I awoke on the Saturday my right leg had turned a bright red and each side of my calf itched like mad On the Sunday my wife drove me to the Minor Injuries Unit MIU at Bridgwater Hospital where I was seen immediately The diagnosis was Cellulitis and I was given a course of fairly strong antibiotics and told to rest with my leg elevated for at least two days As I write my condition is improving and indeed I ve felt almost back to normal for the past couple of days except I tire easily The redness is now confined to my ankle so I m definitely recovering My next ultra is the Chiltern at the end of September by which time I ve no doubt I ll be raring to go Just to add the MIU staff were absolutely brilliant I was well looked after I love the NHS th June The last couple of virtual ultras were fairly short and over too soon so I thought I d go for a longer one this time and started the Land s End to John O Groats A reminder I need to do actual ultras and virtual ultras a year to meet my goal of ultras by my th birthday Saturday th JuneSerendipitous meeting tonight outside the Youth hostel we were staying in We were too late to see the Wheelbarrow race which takes place each year in Kington on this weekend but Alan Alex and I got chatting to a group who had come away after watching it We started chatting to them telling them what a friendly place Kington was Before we knew it one of the group whose name was Adam had invited us to the Olde Tavern where he would buy all five of us a pint They were insistent so we grabbed Mick and Andy and hot footed it down there The place was absolutely buzzing we found our friend and true to his word he bought us all a pint of the local brew and very nice it was too I could have stayed on and made a night of it but common sense prevailed and we went back to the hostel The walk during the day was excellent preparation for my next ultra the SWC with k of off road hills and dales th May By the time the IoW challenge rolled around I had walked over k in preparation A few hill reps not many and quite a few stair climbs but I felt good and ready This was my post on Facebook the day before our adventure started Well it s all systems go everything packed taxi booked for the a m train tickets for trip to Basingstoke where I m to meet my son Then it s down to Portsmouth ferry to Fishbourne on the IoW and then on to the hotel We re booked for a start on Saturday morning but we need to get there an hour before to register This is the bit I don t particularly like I m not the most organised and I won t really start to enjoy the adventure until we re registered and we can join in the pre event Zumba warm up Only then can I truly relax and turn to the job in hand which is to get to the other side of the island in one piece And then do the same again on Sunday so we end up back where we started With over k travelled in training this year I should be OK But I ve got a myriad things buzzing round my head Will the taxi arrive Will the trains run on time Have I got all the bases covered have I packed everything Have I packed too much I m not so worried about the weight I ve been training regularly with kg in my rucksack and I know I haven t got that much So now it s the waiting Hope you like my new get up I ll be flying both the Viva and the Vegan Runners flag around the k route I aim to do two things with my efforts this weekend and the two other ultras I have planned for this year I m hoping that my efforts will attract a lot of support for Viva who do amazing work on behalf of the animals And I also want to show what s possible on plant based nutrition I want to show you can be fit and healthy as a vegan into old age should I ever get there As it turned out everything went to plan So long story short we gathered in the pre event area heard the intro from Dave the MC did the Zumba to warm up and off we went The weather was perfect temperature of around C for most of both days overcast with no rain The island is beautiful as we d been told and the coastline although hilly in places was quite manageable The only downside was the thick viscous mud which we were advised to wade through rather than try and skirt because the sloping edges could be quite tricky to navigate In fact we came across one guy who d fallen and broken his leg heard later he d been looked after fine I was pretty pleased with the way I felt at the end of the second day the atmosphere at the finish line was just amazing and invigorating So much so that I felt impelled to put in a sprint finish So that was my th ultra next one is the SWC in early August so I may do a Virtual one in the meantime to keep me on track th Feb And it s k again this week which included hill reps and stair climbing reps Quite pleased with my speed today I was going at over kph on a couple of stretches Met a lovely family dad and two kids he was a runner and told me his MIL was a vegan and also a runner Earlier in the week I met a group of traffic wardens and community police who were very receptive to my message Probably shifted about leaflets through the week to dog walkers parents with young children people standing around anyone I feel I can strike up a conversation with As I offer a leaflet after we ve exchanged a couple of pleasantries I ll often say something like I give these out to anyone I come across with a nice smile and you ve got a lovely smile Always goes down well th Jan No walk for me this morning had to hang around whilst we had a couple of workmen over But when my grandson went to bed this evening his dad and I went out for a brisk k Gives me k for the week with possibly a few more tomorrow th Jan k this morning overcast but not so cold at C Met a guy Ed who told me he had been diagnosed with diabetes type and also that he d had Covid recently and was finding it difficult to shake it off I gave him a leaflet and told him about the film What the Health to help with the diabetes and about Dr Dean Ornish s recent assertion that the effects of Covid and long covid can be substantially mitigated by the adoption of some simple lifestyle changes link to come I also shared my story with a lovely couple by the canal who showed me the enormous bag of litter they had picked up that morning k so far this week and with my son coming down for the weekend I ve no doubt I ll add a few more th Jan Just the k today had a few chores to do before I could get out Met lovely young guys from the local arts college Later I came across two broadband fitters Bertie and who were installing fibre optic cable told me that we could expect them in our area in a month or so th Jan Once again a bright sunny day just perfect for walking so I got k in mostly along the local canal Met two walking groups in one of which the WI walking group I came across Carole Smith an old friend another I knew through my old mentor Stuart Gunn I also met a postie Jen who was very keen to give veganism another shot So I pointed out the challenge com part of my leaflet which she was very pleased about I must have handed out about or more leaflets altogether including to several dog walkers and a bird watcher who pointed out a kingfisher to me rd Jan I meet some lovely people handing out my leaflets on my training walks And this morning was no exception friendly scaffolders and a mum and dad with a young child on his training bike k in bright sunshine perfect weather for a brisk walk k so far this year aiming for k a week with still months to go th Jan I m now officially in training for the IOW Challenge even though there are still months to go I need something to motivate me to get out So this is it I did k the first week of the NY and k the second and I ve done k so far this week so my total is k I don t have any set training programme I ll carry on getting out there as often as possible and just get the miles in st January I d been looking for a Virtual Challenge to give myself the motivation to keep moving and also to keep to my goal of actual ultras and virtual ultras a year So I signed up for the Actioon Challenge Winter Walk to Lapland There were various distances on offer I chose the k route from Russia to Lapland Much to my delight the distance I had travelled from the th November which had been uploaded to Strava were acknowledged so I was already kilometres into my challenge By Christmas Eve I had covered k and my son and I decided to go for a walk over the Quantocks aiming for up to k on the day In the event because of a few niggles we called it a day at k We were happy with that This leaves k with days left since we re seeing family over this period It s going to be a bit tight In the event with the help of k on the day before NYE and k on NYD I finally managed it Phew So I ve now done ultras with three more next year I only need more Virtual to be up to date with my ultras by my th birthday My programme for next year is fairly set I think I ve signed up to the IoW k challenge over days at the end of April the SWC again mainly because it s on my doorstep and the Chiltern deferred since last year Sunday th September Yesterday my son and I attempted the Thames Path Challenge k continuous The conditions were great and we were both feeling good We did the first k in under hours including pit stops where we ve learned not to sit down getting going again is so much harder when you ve been relaxing in a chair We figured if we could keep up k per hour for the next we d do the whole distance in under hrs That was our mistake we pushed on too fast in the dark and at k I tripped over a malignant tree root and banged my head on the path I got up feeling not too bad but then I felt faint for a few seconds so we decided to quit We managed to get to the next rest stop at k so that remains my one day distance record up from the k on the Jurassic Coast Challenge One day I ll manage the k continuous but not this year or even next but maybe when we re thinking of attempting the TPC again figuring that if we take a lot more care after dark we could do it Our next challenge is the IoW k over days in April After that I ve entered the SCW again in August and the Chiltern at the end of September Sunday th August Yesterday I and my new friend Tom Pickering who took the place of my son Ben who couldn t make it because of childcare duties completed the k South West Coast Challenge in hours and minutes including about an hour and a half at the rest stops It was a complete blast but I ll have to tell the story about this in the morning I m shattered ATM Saturday th August The South West Coast Challenge A loop from Dunster along the coast to Porlock up over Dunkery Beacon then back down to Dunster again Tom had come into the picture when he advertised on Facebook for older Vegan Runners naturally I put my name forward Tom is a film maker who is producing a film I Could Never Go Vegan exposing and rebutting all the myths surrounding Veganism He had interviewed me in Taunton for the film and wanted to see me in action When my son had to pull out Tom took his place and a worthy companion he proved to be We set off at along with about others along the road to Minehead past Butlins then joined the SW coastal path past Bossington to Porlock Weir where we swung inland This is where the climbing began in earnest I d naively thought that after the climb from Minehead up Dunkery in July last the climb round the back of Dunkery would be easier Well it may not have been as steep but it was steep steep and long The climb seemed to go on for ever Some other ultra marathoners maintained that this was tougher than the first half of the Jurassic Coast Challenge but I couldn t agree with that Every so often Tom would point his camera at me and ask how I was feeling Thankfully I was always able to say Doing fine thanks Tom And every pit stop which were roughly every k I would do press ups just to show what a vegan can do and Tom caught a couple of these sets on camera th May Well we did it we now have the Jurassic Coast Challenge under our belts albeit a truncated one explanation to come I d like to welcome all the wonderful friends I made yesterday on the challenge to my blog I handed out about leaflets all told about or so to people I met on the journey and had a conversation with and the rest whilst waiting for the taxi scheduled to arrive at am I just took all my remaining leaflets which I had intended to hand out during the course of the nd day and gave one to everyone sitting eating their meals either on completion of their challenge or fuelling up to carry them through the nd half Everyone who took a leaflet was interested in my story it was lovely to have that brief contact with you all but I just wish I had had time to get to know you all and listen to your stories Maybe on another challenge Here s how I got started on my Ultra journey It s a pretty long blog but the gist of it is in the first few paragraphs I told many of you that my arthritis disappeared after I adopted plant based nutrition here is a blog post I wrote about it I ve got more much more to write about concerning the JCC but that ll have to wait until tomorrow I m just a bit shattered ATM th May What A Day The day long anticipated and will live long in the memory had finally arrived and it got off to a very good start The taxi driver who took my son and I from Wareham to Corfe Castle took off the bill to give us each for our chosen charities Lovely woman I m not a worrier but it s fair to say I m always more concerned about the logistics of the event rather than the event itself talk about getting your priorities wrong as it turned out So I m always relieved when all the formalities are over and we ve been checked in And there we were surrounded by hundreds of eager smiling faces just waiting for the off Bit of zumba type warm up exercise a speech from Mike the MC he of the purple suit welcoming us to the event and telling us to enjoy ourselves and we were off at around The terrain to the first pitstop at k and the second at k was relatively uneventful couple of fairly easy climbs between each but we were all fresh and keen to get the miles in Danish pastries and hot drinks were on offer at the first pitstop as a vegan we re told to ask for stuff as it s put by for us Huge plates of biscuits were also on offer I grabbed a few bourbons knowing they were vegan not sure about the rest We were very disciplined we d planned on only spending minutes at each of the minor stops we were on our way again after only At the second stop some form of vegan sausage rolls were available which weren t great since they left a film of grease on the palate I had a couple of Greggs sausage rolls with me so I had one of those Not so disciplined this time since we spent about minutes at this rest stop It was on the next leg the k to Lulworth Cove that we really began to be challenged Each steep ascent and descent was swiftly followed by another l ll let these pics tell the story Some of these hills I have to say were brutal The walking poles were an absolute necessity for me on the steepest ascents my technique was to put both poles a few inches in front of me take two paces through the gate they formed then reposition the poles a little in front of me It was slow going but I found it the only way Ben and I had intended to do the full k continuous but on the last leg towards the halfway point Ben told me he didn t want to carry on after Weymouth the halfway stage at k He d begun to feel unwell but he d done brilliantly since he d only come off antibiotics the day before So we were content with that k achieved in hours with about hours rest As it turned out it was a very wise fortunate decision since the weather turned nasty an hour or so afterwards and the other contestants had to complete in pouring rain So that s our th ultra done and dusted next one is the South West Coast k at the beginning of August th May Been out every day this week clocking up an average of k each time with a k day earlier In the absence of decent hills I m doing lots of stair climbing in preparation for the fearsome hills on the JCC we ve been warned about my record is a stint of times up the stairs and down the ramp Carrying at least kg in the rucksack which is about the weight I ll be carrying on the ultra With only days to go most of our preparations are in place and I think I m as ready as I m going to be next week I ll probably just do about k a day ticking over as it were My programme this year also includes two k events the SWC C in August and the Chiltern in September As I ve opted for the full charity fundraiser I need to raise for the k event and each for the two k events so for the year As I write I ve already raised over with months to go so my donors are doing me proud th March My story so far After the wonderful weekend my son and I had on the South West Coast Coast ultra marathon in July we ve both become addicted and cannot wait to repeat the experience We followed this up with a k Virtual Trek to Kilimanjaro actually a days hike over the Chilterns Finally for several weeks before Christmas we completed a k Virtual Trek to the North Pole I ve now set myself the goal of completing ultra marathons by my th birthday I m ATM so that means ultras I m thinking real ultras and virtual ones every year for the next years I m extremely fortunate in that my son is keen to join me in this endeavour and our intention is to do the bulk of these together We ve already done as I said here s the story of the SWC C and here s the Virtual Trek to Kilimanjaro story and we ve both signed up for the km Jurassic Coast Challenge in May Unfortunately for my plans at the end of December I suffered a broken leg so that s put my training on the back burner for the next couple of months My leg has been placed in a fairly fragile cast to begin with and I mustn t put any weight on it which makes moving around on crutches quite tricky I should get a more permanent cast next week sometime Since we don t have a downstairs toilet and it s hard work going up and down and I get tired pretty quickly I m staying upstairs most of the time I have to go up the stairs backwards sitting down which is a tad undignified I have to say But it does give me an extra workout Going downstairs is a lot easier since we have two handrails and I ve found if I grip these I can hop down okay The cast finally came off on Feb th and I ve been walking daily since then Beginning with an average of k a day I m now th March doing over k a day I m also back to doing my press ups and since I haven t been doing them for months I need to catch up so I m doing every evening

Karol Adamiak I want to tell you about a relatively typical neighbourhood in my city There are two vegan sushi restaurants three vegan ramen spots There are a few vegan delis All the convenience stores have a vegan section There s an abundance of vegan bakeries There s a place that does vegan peking duck it s good I promise Many of these vegan places proudly have a rainbow flag on display I m not talking about Los Angeles or New York I m not even talking about Copenhagen My neighbourhood is called r dmie cie The vegan paradise I m talking about it s Warsaw If you don t believe me well Warsaw has been ranked among the top vegan cities in the world by HappyCow a vegan ranking website for the past six years In it was National Geographic s number one vegan city in the world Maybe your perception of Poland is all kielbasa sausage and conservative politics Herring and hate It s more complicated than that In the past two decades there has been a quiet vegan revolution in the country In reality it shouldn t be too much of a shock that Polish food lends itself well to veganism Prior to falling under the long shadow of the iron curtain Polish cuisine was mostly plant based Only the aristocracy had easy access to meat fish and dairy products Most of the people in the country were peasants and they ate what they grew The cuisine was full of root vegetables potatoes and earthy greens This was a plant based diet by default not ideology As today this cuisine was heavy on soups and stews An old favourite was a vegetable soup flavoured with sugar and cinnamon to which beer was added at the end to create a yeasted acidity That one didn t stand the test of time Cracovian Jews used to make obwarzanek parboiled rye dough shaped into a circle and sell it from carts on the streets of the city This fared a little better it likely inspired what we know today as bagels In the communist era meat was a luxury despite everyone s alleged equality Meat production was inefficient which meant ordinary people did not have the money to afford the scant supply This meant people craved meat as a status symbol particularly because the socialist elite did have access to animal proteins When the USSR collapsed people wanted to eat meat and as market forces entered agriculture and people gradually gained disposable income they spent heavily on it But as Poland became a mature liberal democracy appetites changed For the younger generation that grew up in a time of relative abundance animal products were so commonplace they failed to have much lustre I lived in Madrid as an Erasmus student and I found it hard to sustain my social life without eating meat Whereas in Warsaw I honestly cannot recall the last time I went to a restaurant that did not have a vegan option in their offering Micha Korkosz AKA Rozkoszny told me Rozkoszny is one of the most prominent vegetarian food influencers in the country with more than k followers on instagram His cookbooks Fresh from Poland and Polish d which offer vegetarian twists on classic Polish recipes have sold copies and been translated into three languages In some cases Rozkoszny celebrates the plant based foods of old Poland Schabowy z kani parasol mushroom schnitzel is a traditional recipe one known to seemingly every Polish grandma Similar to a regular schnitzel the mushroom is prepped paneed and then fried often served alongside young boiled potatoes and mizeria Polish tzatziki In other cases he takes traditional dishes and gives them a modern twist to make them vegan urek is a popular soup traditionally made with stock of smoked pork ribs and served with various kinds of kielbasa sausage But in urek as proposed by Rozkoszny the soup is made with miso hardly a traditional Polish staple but now widely available and roasted mushrooms Before becoming a bestselling author and influencer Rozkoszny studied politics and sociology He s attuned to the fact that what you eat can be a political statement He once conducted a study in which he interviewed a number of Polish MPs on their diets and tried to map their politics The more left leaning a politician the more likely they were to have a vegetarian diet and eat international cuisines he told me A study by Ipsos showed similar results Polish politicians were asked What actions are you willing to take to help fight climate change Among politicians from the left stated that they would give up meat versus a mere for the right wing Law and Justice party Veganism tends to be perceived as a pejorative term according to Anna Spurek the chief operating officer at the Green REV Institute Poland s first vegan thinktank The meat lobby and interest groups use it to polarise society It has been a common refrain of rightwing politicians that veganism is anti Polish that it is a similar form of propaganda to the LGBT agenda and that vegans are insane and detached from reality she said But veganism should be an idea that transcends neat political brackets For one Spurek thinks that the Polish idea of solidarno solidarity and the name of the political movement that helped bring down communism in Poland can also include the concept of interspecies unity and green politics And in a way veganism represents a return to Poland s peasant roots and a more conscious and healthy way of eating Across Poland even in rural areas diets are increasingly plant based While veganism has been caught in Poland s increasingly polarised politics its impact on the culture is obvious everywhere With Barclay Bram I run a vegan Polish supper club in London called Bracia it means brothers in Polish Many people in London comment that this seems like something that could only happen here and we see their surprise when we tell them how vegan friendly Poland is Recently we ve been doing events back in Warsaw In February we re taking over Lotos a traditional restaurant open since famous for its n ki w galarecie legs in jelly literally a chicken soup served cold so the collagen has become gelatinous with veg and carrots suspended in it The owner Hanna Szyma ska told us she s looking forward to putting out a vegan menu for the night You have to move with the times

Have you heard of that old saying Don t knock it till you try it It means that should give new things a try before you can decide whether or not you like them and it s true But while this is a very simple idea sometimes it can be hard to try new things especially when it contradicts an action that has been done for a long time like eating animals and animal derived products Getting food from animals has been the way of humans since we first walked the Earth Excluding certain regions and cultures like India Ethiopia Eritrea and parts of Africa and Asia the vast majority of the world relies on an animal based diet But as recent studies have shown our dependence on food from animals is becoming too costly in several ways Animal agriculture is a major contributor to climate change producing more greenhouse gases than cars trains and airplanes Center for Biological Diversity Animal agriculture destroys natural habitats and ecosystems to raise livestock and grow feed crops Center for Biological Diversity The livestock industry destroys forests and grasslands Stanford University Livestock accounts for half of all antibiotic use globally increasing antibiotic resistance to people who eat them Stanford University The livestock industry uses a lot of water and other natural resources Vegetarian Times The cost of maintaining a diet that relies majorly on animals is becoming too much to continue However research has shown that if everyone shifted to a plant based diet we would reduce global land use for agriculture by Our World in Data But encouraging everyone on Earth to switch to a plant based diet is nowhere near as simple as it sounds That s why this organization has staged an annual month long event to inspire people to join the global plant based revolution Experiment with life by exploring and trying new things Robin S Baker Simple Idea to Grand Movement Formed in the founders of this organization were Matthew Glover a passionate animal welfare advocate and Jane Land a dedicated environmentalist The idea came from Glover s desire to make a positive impact on animal welfare and the environment Inspired by similar campaigns like Movember a global charity event that takes place annually in November to raise awareness and funds for men s health issues they wanted to create an event that would encourage people to try veganism for a month The first Veganuary campaign took place in January and it started as a small crowdfunded initiative in the UK They aimed to show that veganism is fun and easy and to help people understand the benefits of a plant based diet Over the years Veganuary has grown into a global movement with millions of participants from around the world a shining example of a simple idea turning into a significant movement Day Vegan Challenge The Day Vegan Challenge is the cornerstone of Veganuary s campaign Participants pledge to follow a vegan diet for the entire month of January This means avoiding all animal products including meat dairy eggs and honey Daily Support Each day participants receive an email filled with tips recipes nutritional advice and motivational content These emails are designed to guide participants through their vegan journey providing support and inspiration Resources Veganuary offers a wide variety of delicious and easy to make vegan recipes These range from breakfast options to main courses and desserts ensuring that participants have plenty of meal ideas to choose from Customizable meal plans are provided to help participants organize their meals and make grocery shopping easier These plans cater to different dietary needs and preferences such as gluten free or high protein diets Educational Content Participants receive information on how to maintain a balanced vegan diet and ensure they are getting all the necessary nutrients Participants also receive educational content on the health benefits of a vegan diet including potential improvements in heart health weight management and energy levels Community Support Veganuary s social media platforms serve as a hub for participants to connect share experiences and find encouragement from others on the same journey Throughout January Veganuary hosts various events and webinars featuring vegan experts chefs and nutritionists to provide additional support and inspiration Motivation and Inspiration Participants are inspired by success stories from previous years showcasing how others have benefited from trying a vegan diet Fun challenges and activities are also included to keep participants engaged and motivated throughout the month The Day Vegan Challenge is designed to make the transition to a vegan diet as smooth and enjoyable as possible It s a great way for anyone curious about veganism to give it a try with plenty of support and resources Meal Plans Veganuary s meal plans are designed to help participants easily transition to a vegan diet by providing well balanced delicious and easy to make meals These plans take the guesswork out of meal planning and ensure participants get all the nutrients they need What the Meal Plans Include Weekly Menus Veganuary provides weekly meal plans that outline breakfast lunch dinner and snack options for each day These menus are carefully curated to include a variety of flavors and ingredients ensuring participants enjoy their meals and stay motivated Recipes Each meal plan comes with detailed recipes including ingredient lists and step by step instructions The recipes are designed to be easy to follow even for those who are new to vegan cooking Nutritional Balance The meal plans are created to ensure a balanced diet including sufficient protein vitamins and materials Veganuary takes into account different dietary needs and preferences such as gluten free high protein or low carb options Special Features Shopping Lists To make meal planning even easier Veganuary provides shopping lists for each week s meal plans These lists are organized by food category making grocery shopping more efficient and less stressful Customizable Options Participants can customize the meal plans to suit their tastes and dietary requirements For example if someone prefers more protein rich meals they can swap out certain recipes for others that better meet their needs Seasonal Ingredients The meal plans often incorporate seasonal ingredients making it easier for participants to find fresh and affordable produce International Flavors To keep things exciting Veganuary s meal plans feature a variety of cuisines from around the world This helps participants explore new flavors and discover new favorite dishes Example Meal Plan Here s an example of what a typical day in a Veganuary meal plan might look like Breakfast Banana Oat Pancakes with Maple Syrup Lunch Lentil and Vegetable Soup with a Side of Whole Grain Bread Dinner Chickpea and Spinach Curry served with Brown Rice Snack Hummus with Carrot and Cucumber Sticks Benefits Simplifies Meal Planning The meal plans make it easy to plan vegan meals without having to think too much about what to cook each day Reduces Food Waste By providing specific shopping lists and recipes participants are less likely to buy unnecessary items leading to less food waste Encourages Variety With a diverse range of recipes participants can enjoy a wide variety of meals and avoid getting bored with their diet These meal plans are a fantastic resource for anyone taking part in Veganuary as they make the transition to a vegan diet both enjoyable and manageable Celebrity Cookbook The Celebrity Cookbook is a collection of vegan recipes contributed by various celebrities who support the Veganuary campaign These celebrities come from different backgrounds including actors musicians athletes and chefs Their involvement helps raise awareness about veganism and provides participants with diverse and inspiring recipes Content of the Cookbook Celebrity Contributors The cookbook features recipes from well known figures such as Joaquin Phoenix Billie Eilish Paul McCartney and many others These celebrities share their favorite vegan dishes along with personal anecdotes and tips for maintaining a plant based diet Variety of Recipes The cookbook includes a wide range of recipes from breakfasts and snacks to main courses and desserts This variety ensures that participants have plenty of options to choose from whether they are looking for something quick and easy or a more elaborate meal Nutritional Information Each recipe comes with nutritional information helping participants make informed choices about their diet The cookbook also includes tips on how to balance meals and ensure proper nutrient intake Personal Stories and Insights Alongside the recipes celebrities often share their personal stories and reasons for adopting a vegan lifestyle These insights can be motivating and provide a deeper connection to the campaign Special Features Exclusive Recipes Some recipes in the cookbook are exclusive and can t be found elsewhere This adds a unique element to the Veganuary experience Easy to Follow Instructions The recipes are designed to be accessible with clear step by step instructions This makes it easy for participants regardless of their cooking experience to recreate the dishes at home Beautiful Photography The cookbook is filled with vibrant high quality photos of the dishes making it visually appealing and inspiring Culinary Diversity The recipes reflect a wide range of culinary traditions and flavors showcasing the versatility of plant based cooking Example Recipes Here are a few of the types of recipes you might find in the Celebrity Cookbook Billie Eilish s Vegan Pancakes A delicious and fluffy breakfast option made with simple plant based ingredients Paul McCartney s Lentil Shepherd s Pie A hearty and comforting main dish that s perfect for a family meal Joaquin Phoenix s Chocolate Avocado Mousse A rich and creamy dessert that s both indulgent and healthy Benefits Inspiration The involvement of celebrities can inspire and motivate participants to stick with their vegan challenge Community Knowing that well known figures are also part of the vegan movement can create a sense of community and belonging Enjoyment The variety and quality of recipes make the vegan journey enjoyable and exciting The Celebrity Cookbook is a wonderful resource for anyone participating in Veganuary offering delicious recipes and a connection to the broader vegan community Coaching Emails The Coaching Emails are a key part of Veganuary s support system designed to provide participants with daily guidance and motivation throughout their day vegan journey Participants who sign up for the Day Vegan Challenge receive daily emails throughout January These emails are crafted to offer a combination of practical advice delicious recipes nutritional tips and motivational content Key Components of the Coaching Emails Daily Inspiration Each email begins with a positive and motivating message to keep participants encouraged and focused on their goals Nutritional Advice The emails provide essential information on how to maintain a balanced and healthy vegan diet This includes tips on getting enough protein vitamins and minerals as well as advice on meal planning and preparation Recipes Participants receive a variety of recipes for breakfast lunch dinner and snacks These recipes are easy to follow and designed to fit into a busy lifestyle They help participants million people worldwide received Veganuary s resources support through emails social media podcasts and YouTube channel Over new vegan products new menu items launched for Veganuary globally Veganuary in its mission to help the world go vegan in several ways Sign up for the Day Vegan Challenge and give the vegan lifestyle a try in January Share your Veganuary journey on social media to inspire others Encourage friends and family to join you in the Veganuary challenge If you have a blog or a publication share your experiences and the benefits of veganism to reach a broader audience My first introduction to veganism was in high school My best friend at the time band camp was vegan and at first I gave her shit but naturally as best friends do I wanted to do it too sorta I started out as pescatarian and that lasted for years until I graduated and moved to the midwest not the most plant based diet accommodating region at the time I continued to be pescatarian off and on until this past year when I made the jump all in to veganism Let me be honest I m a fat vegan I love all my veggies and my health has improved my poops are fantastic and our grocery bill smaller but ya girl likes pizza and ice cream and burgers and CHEESE So I m always on the hunt for really good vegan dupes of those animal products I should mention I don t cook I can toast toast scramble some JUST egg vegan brand and I m getting better at crisping up some tofu to add to my second rice and frozen veggies My wonderful husband Cody is my personal chef And paid chef for others but I m pretty sure he cooks his best meals for me Cody is not vegan but because of my changes he has dramatically reduced his consumption of animal products He loves the challenge of cooking with new ingredients and will let me know what he likes and doesn t For example he s not a fan of vegan cheese the affordable stuff everyday use cheese can be gummy Living in WV options are limited But there are many options even in WV that have surprised us for being both vegan and tasty With all that said here are of my favorite vegan dupes that helped me transition from animal products to veganism These are Cody approved as well Tofu I know The dreaded enemy I was NOT a tofu girlie until I went vegan Now I crave it And there are so many ways to cook this affordable food There is a learning curve but the internet has so many great recipes and tips tricks making tofu a staple in many of our meals now With some rice and veggies it s a quick and satiating lunch after a workout which is perfect for someone who may not have the time or skills Gardein F sh Sticks Hear me out on this one Trust me I looked at that box and laughed Not only is real frozen fish hit or miss but a dupe It s so good Yes you read that right It s soo good Look if you re not a fish person this probably isn t for you But me the former pescatarian seafood was the last animal flesh I wanted to leave in the past These f sh sticks make up for those nights when a good ol fish and chips hits the spot These hit the spot Impossible Meat Impossible is out here doing their thing Impossible Whopper at Burger King Impossible burger options at restaurants Even Cracker Barrel has an Impossible substitution available The taste look everything is the same Price Pricier than the animal flesh option but a great swap for Meatless Mondays MorningStar Chik n Nuggets MorningStar is accessible and affordable available in any chain grocery store I frequently buy their bacon but Cody does not like it It definitely is not the crispy skin we grew up with but does the job for me Their standout product is their nuggets The buffalo THE BUFFALO chick n wings are it Load me up They get me in the mood for sports and summer and hanging out with friends Perfect option especially for those chicken nugget kiddos they have not buffalo flavor as well Country Crock Plant Based Cream AND Butter This suggestion came from the chef himself I know technically this list is now Easy Vegan Swaps but we have been surprised with how comparable these are to the animal version I don t use the cream but Cody has used it to make white chik n chili Swedish meatballs mashed potatoes and anywhere heavy cream is needed Many receipes call for coconut cream to replace cow cream but it doesn t quite do the job like this stuff And their butter I m pretty sure it s just margarine but it s good And softens quickly out of the fridge which is great for someone like me who forgets to soften butter for those cookies I want to bake RIGHT NOW
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Aaron Abke aaronabke

With growing awareness of how the foods we eat impact our health more and more people are considering a switch to a plant focused style of eating From veganism to vegetarianism to a complete raw food diet the world of plant based nutrition certainly offers a diverse array of choices But is a plant based diet the right choice for you In this blog post we ll explore the different types of plant based diets we ll discuss some of their potential benefits and risks and offer some basic tips on how you can make a successful transition into this new style of eating Understanding Plant Based Nutrition Plant based diets may differ in specifics but the one thing they have in common is a focus on whole unprocessed plant foods such as fruits vegetables grains legumes nuts and seeds Here are the primary types and how they can be customized to suit your individual preferences and nutritional needs Veganism Vegans abstain from all animal products including meat dairy eggs and even honey This diet is based solely on plant foods Some vegans even abstain from wearing clothing that has been made with animal fur or skins such as leather and wool Vegetarianism Vegetarians avoid meal but may include dairy and eggs in their diets This is referred to as a lacto ovo vegetarian Pescatarian Pescatarians consume fish along with plant based foods but they avoid other types of meat Flexitarian Flexitarians primarily follow a plant based diet but they occasionally include a small amount of animal products Raw Foodists Raw foodists consume uncooked and unprocessed plant foods believing that cooking destroys essential nutrients Potential Benefits of Plant Based Diets and a Note on Bio Individuality Switching to a plant based diet can lead to remarkable health improvements for many individuals However the reasons behind these changes can often be multifaceted For those coming from heavily processed diets the shift to more natural plant based foods naturally marks a significant improvement Nonetheless each person s unique bio individual chemical makeup means that what works for one may not work for another Factors like genetics metabolism lifestyle and response to stress all play a role underscoring the importance of personalized nutrition While reducing processed foods alone can enhance well being the specific impact of switching to a plant based diet for the long haul will still vary from person to person Staying attuned to the body s signals and being open to adjustments along the way allows individuals to fine tune their dietary choices and optimize their health even further on their plant based journey That said here are some of the potential health benefits one might experience through switching to a more plant based style of eating Improved Heart Health Plant based diets are often associated with lower cholesterol levels reduced risk of heart disease and lower blood pressure Weight Management A plant based diet rich in whole unprocessed foods can aid in weight loss and maintenance of a healthy weight Enhanced digestion The fiber and enzyme content in whole plant foods supports a healthy microbiome and digestive system Increased Nutrient Intake Plant based diets provide a wide varieties of essential nutrients and antioxidants Potential Risks of Plant Based Diets Nutrient Deficiencies Inadequate planning may lead to deficiencies in nutrients like vitamin B iron calcium and omega fatty acids Proper supplementation and dietary choices can mitigate these risks and this is one reason working with a qualified practitioner when making this change can be so beneficial Protein Intake Plant based diets can provide ample protein but it is essential to combine various protein courses for a complete amino acid profile Food allergies Relying heavily on certain plant foods can exacerbate allergies or sensitivities Eating Disorders Those with a history of eating disorders should approach any restrictive diet including plant based diets with caution and professional guidance A Balanced Approach to Plant Based Nutrition When transitioning to a plant based diet it is essential to recognize that there can be both healthy and unhealthy approaches Opting for a balanced switch involves a thoughtful incorporation of plant based foods rich in nutrients vitamins and minerals This may include a variety of fresh fruits vegetables whole grains legumes nuts and seeds These whole foods offer a wealth of nutritional benefits and can form the foundation of a nourishing plant based diet On the other hand an imbalanced shift may involve relying too heavily on processed meat alternatives which can be laden with additives preservatives and high levels of sodium Consuming excessive starches refined carbohydrates and sugary vegan snacks can also be detrimental to health This kind of plant based diet can lack the essential nutrients required to for overall well being and can lead to potential health issues if not carefully balanced To make a successful transition to a plant based lifestyle individuals should prioritize whole minimally processed foods while being mindful of their nutrient intake Consulting a registered practitioner can be incredibly beneficial in ensuring that the dietary choices you make align with your unique health goals Tips for Transitioning to a Plant Based Diet Gradual Approach Start by incorporating more plant based meals into your diet and gradually reducing animal products Variety is Key Explore a wide range of plant based whole foods to ensure you get a diverse array of nutrients Educate Yourself Learn about the nutritional requirements of a plant based diet to make the best informed choices for your health Seek Support Join a community work with a practitioner or connect with others in plant based nutrition forums to gain insights and encouragement from others Final Thoughts A plant based diet can be a powerful choice for promoting personal health and longevity By understanding the different types of plant based diets their benefits and potential risks you can make the best informed decisions that align with your unique goals and values And remember A successful transition involves education support and an open mind so whether you re a curious beginner or a seasoned enthusiast our Plant Based Nutrition program is available to support and empower you along your journey Embrace the power of plants and embark on an exciting path to vibrant well being
