Some people might view the question of Jesus relationship to veganism as unknowable and irrelevant Understanding it however unlocks one of the keys to His attitude toward food and how we should view it Jesus ate like a Jew to reach the JewsWhile there is perhaps no definitive statement on Jesus dietary preferences there are strong clues that tell us how He ate Jesus was under constant scrutiny and whenever His actions deviated from the religious traditions of His day He was challenged If Jesus had strayed from the normative kosher food laws people would have almost certainly reacted There would have been questions from the Pharisees about why He refused to eat meat We have to conclude that when God came into this world as a man He ate like a Jew to reach the Jews The other thing we should note is how important food was to His mission Consider how many accounts we have of meals that Jesus shared Matthew Luke Luke Luke Luke John Mark And even when his meals with sinners drew criticism He persisted in them If I were being called a glutton and a drunkard Matthew Luke Luke I d start pulling back but Jesus didn t It seems clear that meals were more than meals to Jesus They were a part of His mission and He ate like a Jew to reach the Jews You might be tempted to think that this attitude toward food was just a peculiarity of Jesus But consider what happened next Peter ate like a Gentile to reach the GentilesWe often think of the apostle Paul as the catalyst for the Christian mission to the non Jewish world There was something critical that happened first however God instituted a new diet In a dramatic vision God showed Peter a sheet full of all kinds of animals and reptiles and birds Acts and told him to kill them and eat them The Old Testament food laws were so ingrained in him that God needed to tell him three times before he got the message This can just feel like a curious incident but it was critical to God s mission to reach the world An overly restrictive diet would be a huge obstacle hindering the ability of Christians to build relationships across cultures It s also why Paul rebuked Peter so sharply when he stopped eating with the Gentile Christians in Galatia Galatians Food isn t just food It s a means of fellowship and mission Paul called people to eat what people serve youWe know that food continued to be a point of contention in the early church Not only was there the issue of Jewish food laws that needed to be overcome but most meat that was sold in the marketplace had been first used in the pagan sacrifices of local temples Christians with delicate consciences felt like they were participating in idolatry by eating such meat and refrained out of conviction Romans While Paul respected their convictions he said If one of the unbelievers invites you to dinner and you are disposed to go eat whatever is set before you without raising any question on the ground of conscience Corinthians As long as your host isn t making a religious act out of it Corinthians don t put up barriers by refusing to eat what they serve Again it shows how important food can be in breaking down walls between people or erecting them Reflecting on these verses isn t intended to talk anyone out of veganism or any other diet Thinking responsibly about what you eat is something that glorifies God and if you re convinced that you ve found a way to do that with a particular food plan that s commendable But the Bible reminds us that what we eat has relational implications as well Considering those implications when we re eating with others is a vital part of fellowship and mission In awe of Him Paul

READ NEXT READ Imagine standing in the supplement aisle surrounded by countless tubs labeled Whey Protein and Plant Protein The choices can be overwhelming but understanding the key differences and benefits of these options can simplify your decision Proteins are essential for muscle repair immune function and overall wellness Among the most popular protein supplements whey and plant proteins each offer unique advantages Whether you re focusing on fitness dietary needs or sustainability this guide will help you identify the best fit for your goals What Is Whey Protein Whey protein is a high quality protein made from cow s milk during the cheese making process After separating the liquid whey from the curds it s processed into a concentrated powder Available in three forms concentrate isolate and hydrolysate whey protein is packed with essential amino acids and absorbs quickly This makes it ideal for muscle repair recovery and overall fitness making it a go to choice for anyone boosting their protein intake For those seeking alternatives to whey explore our guide on Whey Protein Alternatives What Is Plant Protein Plant protein is a nutrient rich plant based alternative to animal derived proteins commonly sourced from peas soy rice hemp and other plants It is widely favored for being vegan friendly hypoallergenic and suitable for individuals with dairy or lactose sensitivities One of the key benefits of plant protein is its versatility in providing essential nutrients like fiber vitamins and minerals in addition to protein When combined from multiple sources such as pea protein and rice it offers a complete amino acid profile supporting muscle growth recovery and overall health For those comparing pea protein vs whey protein pea protein stands out as a sustainable and easily digestible option particularly for those with dietary restrictions Difference Between Whey Protein vs Plant Protein Nutrition Whey offers a complete amino acid profile and higher protein content while plant protein requires blending for completeness Digestibility Whey absorbs quickly but may cause discomfort for lactose intolerant individuals plant protein digests slower and is gentler on the stomach Dietary Needs Whey suits non vegans without lactose issues while plant protein is vegan friendly and hypoallergenic Environmental Impact Whey has a higher carbon footprint plant protein is more sustainable and eco friendly Choose based on your health goals dietary preferences and environmental values Similarity Between Whey Protein vs Plant Protein Despite their differences whey and plant protein share several benefits making both effective choices for various health and fitness goals Muscle Recovery Both support muscle repair and recovery helping to rebuild muscle tissue after workouts Fitness Support They aid in improving strength endurance and overall athletic performance Protein Requirements Both are excellent sources of protein helping to meet daily intake needs for muscle maintenance and overall health Versatility Both come in a variety of flavors and formulations making them easy to incorporate into shakes smoothies and recipes Whether you choose whey or plant protein both can play a crucial role in supporting a balanced and active lifestyle How to Choose the Right Protein for You Choosing the right protein depends on your health goals dietary preferences and lifestyle If quick muscle recovery is your priority whey may be ideal while plant protein is better for those with dietary restrictions or sustainability concerns By understanding your needs whether for muscle building weight loss or overall wellness you can select a protein source that supports your fitness and health journey effectively Learn how to incorporate protein shakes into your routine for maximum benefits in our guide How to Incorporate Protein Shakes into Your Diet Nutritional Comparison Whey protein and plant protein vary in their nutritional profiles but both can support your health and fitness goals Here s a quick comparison Nutrient Whey Protein Plant Protein Protein Content g per serving g per serving varies by source Calories per serving per serving Amino Acid Profile Complete rich in BCAAs leucine isoleucine valine Incomplete but complete when blended e g pea rice Carbohydrates Low g in isolates Moderate g often includes fiber Fats Minimal less than g in isolates Varies g depending on source Whey protein provides a naturally complete amino acid profile with a high leucine content for muscle repair Plant protein while sometimes incomplete achieves similar nutritional value when combined from sources like pea and rice offering added fiber and eco friendliness Digestibility and Absorption Whey protein with a PDCAAS of is quickly digested and absorbed making it ideal for post workout recovery However it may cause discomfort for those with lactose intolerance or dairy allergies Plant proteins like soy PDCAAS and blends of pea and rice digest more slowly providing a sustained release of amino acids They are hypoallergenic and gentler on digestion making them a great option for individuals with dietary sensitivities Whey supports immediate muscle repair while plant proteins offer steady prolonged benefits catering to diverse dietary needs Health and Dietary Considerations Protein choices should align with dietary needs and sensitivities Whey protein while highly nutritious contains lactose and dairy making it unsuitable for vegans or those with lactose intolerance Plant proteins like pea and rice are hypoallergenic and free from common allergens though soy may trigger sensitivities in some For sensitive digestion or specific dietary needs plant based options provide a versatile allergy friendly alternative Always check labels for certifications like vegan or gluten free to ensure compatibility with your preferences Aligning with Fitness Goals Whey protein s fast absorption and high leucine content make it ideal for muscle building and quick recovery Pea protein rich in leucine also supports muscle growth when consumed adequately For weight management whey promotes satiety while fiber rich plant proteins provide lasting fullness and aid digestion Both options effectively support fitness goals based on individual needs Environmental and Ethical Considerations Protein choice impacts more than health it affects the planet Whey protein derived from dairy has a higher carbon footprint due to greenhouse gas emissions and resource intensive livestock farming It also raises concerns about animal welfare in industrial farming practices In contrast plant based proteins are more sustainable requiring fewer resources like water and land and producing lower emissions Their eco friendliness and alignment with ethical diets such as veganism make them a preferred choice for environmentally conscious individuals Choosing plant proteins supports both personal health and a more sustainable ethical food system Find out why a plant based diet is better for the environment in Environmental Reasons for Choosing a Plant Based Diet Pricing Comparison Whey protein especially isolates is often more expensive due to advanced processing while plant proteins are competitively priced but may cost more for blends or organic certifications Whey offers cost effective protein content while plant proteins add value with nutrients and sustainability appealing to eco conscious buyers Conclusion Whey and plant proteins each have unique strengths from whey s fast absorption and complete amino acid profile to plant protein s sustainability and hypoallergenic benefits Your choice should align with your fitness goals dietary preferences and values For those seeking a sustainable nutrient rich option LyfeFuel s plant based protein offers a high quality solution that supports both your health and the planet Take the next step in your wellness journey with a protein that fits your lifestyle FAQs Is plant protein better than whey Is plant protein effective for weight loss How do I choose the right protein for my dietary needs Enter some text Enter some From veganuary com An international team of female scientists will be taking part in Veganuary in one of the world s harshest environments January th An all female team of international scientists is taking part in the Veganuary challenge as they embark on a climate focused Antarctic expedition Veganuary the global movement encouraging people to try a plant based diet for January and beyond has inspired the women to take part even while navigating one of the harshest environments on Earth The scientists are part of the global Homeward Bound leadership programme aimed at women and non binary people from STEMM backgrounds The voyage aims to educate about Antarctica which is particularly vulnerable to global warming and build a community of scientists and leaders committed to fighting climate change The team see their participation in Veganuary as a way to connect their personal actions to their goals of studying and mitigating the climate crisis Most members are extending their participation to the full length of the expedition which runs beyond January In their own words here is why the women are taking part in Veganuary Photos of the participants can be downloaded here Alba Fern ndez Sanl s Molecular Biologist and researcher in Population Health Sciences at University College London Spanish working in London As a teenager I refused to eat mammals which I considered my friends At I also stopped eating chicken and in my twenties I eliminated fish and seafood from my diet In my thirties I cook only with vegetables and I have been participating in Veganuary since Although my initial reasons were animal welfare I am deeply committed to taking action against the climate crisis One simple way to do this is by partially or completely reducing the consumption of animals and their products and generating less waste And despite what many say eating vegan healthy and affordably is possible Emily S Cross Professor of Human Neuroscience and Social Robotics at Macquarie University and University of Glasgow and Director of the Social Brain in Action Laboratory at the Department of Cognitive Science at Macquarie University UK and Australia It is becoming increasingly common knowledge that a plant based diet is healthier for our bodies and the planet However making the switch can be difficult I made it a new year s resolution back in to go from an omnivore diet to strict veganism which I kept up for several years and then reverted back to being pesca vegan I never liked dairy products so vegetarianism was difficult for me but veganism a dream I m embracing Veganuary this year as a chance to show my two young sons that we can eat deliciously healthily and sustainably without animal based products Marta Crespo Agricultural Engineer specialising in renewable energies Spain Joining Veganuary is my way of contributing to the fight against climate change It is an incredibly interesting initiative that allows me to reduce my carbon footprint by directly addressing the use and contamination of water caused by current meat consumption Efforts to reuse or recycle are not enough in the fight against climate change real change begins with reducing So let s start by reducing the consumption and waste of what we put directly into our mouths With it being this easy how can we not give it a try Catherine Barry Molecular Biologist in Oncology Chicago Illinois USA It just so happens that what is best for me is also best for the planet Jess Leck GhostNets Australia Program Coordinator for OceanEarth Foundation Australia If we can live happy and healthy lives without harming others why wouldn t we For me a plant based diet is the easiest way to minimise my impact on this planet and its creatures Devin Fitzpatrick PhD Student University of Calgary Faculty of Veterinary Medicine Canada Production of meat and dairy contribute significantly to climate change and environmental degradation through greenhouse gas emissions habitat destruction and water consumption among others I gave up eating meat over years ago to reduce my impact on the planet and I have decided to go fully plant based for Veganuary to raise awareness of these issues I think Veganuary is a great initiative to get people more familiar with a plant based lifestyle and show them it is possible to be more flexible with their diets for the rest of the year Natalia Atuesta Escobar Environmental Engineer and Biologist specialising in biodiversity conservation and management Colombia I am committed to creating systemic changes to tackle the twin climate and biodiversity crises Through my work I facilitate businesses communities and public sector actors with tools and models to protect nature and enhance sustainable resource use I have not shifted my diet dramatically but am convinced that food is at the core of the solution towards improved livelihoods and environmental impacts I am joining Veganuary by going vegetarian for the duration of the voyage I see this as an opportunity to try a more conscious diet reduce my carbon footprint get rid of some preconceptions and assess ways to incorporate a plant based diet into everyday life Kristina Burrack Immunologist Investigator and Assistant Professor Minnesota USA I m giving Veganuary a try healthy eating is also healthy for the Earth Notes to Editor Veganuary is free to join and people can take part at veganuary com to receive our Celebrity eCookbook the Official Veganuary Starter Kit and daily emails packed with nutritional info delicious recipes meal plans and helpful advice Since Veganuary launched its first pledge in January millions of people coming from almost every country in the world have taken part From humble beginnings on a kitchen table in Yorkshire there are now official Veganuary campaigns in the UK US Germany Chile Argentina India Spain Australia Austria Brazil France Greece Italy Malaysia Mexico Peru Singapore South Africa Switzerland and Canada It has truly become a global phenomenon Contact Toni Vernelli International Head of Policy and Communications Veganuary E toni veganuary com https veganuary com all female antarctic expedition embraces veganuary

Advocates for animal agriculture and for the meat egg and dairy industries are eager to disparage plant based alternatives of all kinds They do it by focusing on ingredient lists and the fact that these foods particularly veggie meats are ultra processed We vegans should be careful that we don t help them Too often people advocating for a plant based diet support the idea that healthy eating relies on foods made with clean ingredients I see it in the comments on social media when I post about the role of plant based meats in vegan diets I see it in the push for a vegan diet that incorporates only whole foods and that shuns anything made with oils or isolated proteins And I ve even seen vegan food companies chime in to disparage their vegan competition One example in my social media feeds comes from the Rebel Cheese company They suggest that you should buy their products because other plant based cheeses are full of garbage I ve tasted several types of Rebel Cheese made famous through the company s appearance on Shark Tank Their products are excellent But if you want to try this cheese you may need to buy it online since it s not widely available in stores Also it costs upwards of per pound plus shipping In our advocacy to help people decrease their intake of cow s milk products do we really want to tell them that their only choice is between a hard to find excessively expensive product or cheese that is full of garbage This kind of rhetoric is unhelpful It s also not true Rebel is far from the only plant based company casting vegan competitors as fake foods To no avail I ve politely asked a number of companies like Pegg vegan eggs and Plant Provisions to consider marketing efforts that don t promote fear of other vegan foods or harmless ingredients Rebel Foods has at least responded to my comments in a friendly way Pegg just deletes them I get that vegan food companies need to make a profit But I also hold them to a certain standard and I don t think it s unfair to do so Plant based companies like Tofurky and Treeline were founded on clearly stated commitments to ethical veganism and continue to maintain those commitments Whether or not the new companies share those goals I would still ask that they at least not make veganism more difficult It s fair to expect that of vegan activists too Here is why more people don t eat vegan foods It s because they like the convenience and taste of meat milk and eggs Why would we vilify foods that give them the convenience and taste they value but without exploiting animals How we talk about vegan food matters Plant based meats plant milks plant based cheese they all help people make the transition to a vegan diet They make it easier to stay vegan They make it more fun to be vegan They allow vegans to recreate dishes and recipes that are part of their culture or meaningful to them in other ways There are many people in the world proponents of animal agriculture and conspiracy minded wellness activists who want us to fear these foods And the more fear they create around these foods the more barriers they effectively create to veganism Don t help them

It s been since mankind first walked the Earth hundreds of thousands of years ago that we have sought food from animals From meat to eggs to dairy to fish animals have been a source of food for all civilizations throughout the ages However do you know the true cost of that steak on your plate It s much higher than you think and not just in the financial sense These are the true costs of our animal based diet Meat production requires a significant amount of water around gallons of water needed to produce pound of beef Water Footprint Calculator Livestock farming occupies of global agricultural land but provides only of the world s calories This leads to deforestation habitat destruction and soil degradation WSP Livestock account for a varied estimate of of global greenhouse gas emissions The Breakthrough Institute of nearly billion animals are raised on factory farms which harms animal welfare the environment and public health Farm Sanctuary These statistics paint a grim picture our animal based agriculture for our ever expanding population is having a devastating effect on the world It s clear that we need to make a change and the best way to start is at the source our diet It s a simple equation fewer animals and animal derived products people eat equals fewer resources spent on resources on animal raising bigger reductions in global emissions and many more animals saved from inhumane treatment The best way to reach this sum is to learn to cut more animals and animal derived products from our diet and practice the way of veganism It requires times more land to produce a gram of protein from cows or sheep than it does to produce it from pulses such as chickpeas or soybeans Henry Mance What Is Veganism Veganism is a way of living that seeks to exclude as far as possible and practical all forms of exploitation of and cruelty to animals for food clothing and any other purpose This means that a vegan diet avoids all animal products including meat dairy eggs and honey and often extends to not using products like leather and certain cosmetics that involve animal testing or animal derived ingredients Difference Between a Vegan Lifestyle and Adopting Some Vegan Practices Vegan Lifestyle Diet Completely plant based no animal products Clothing Avoids leather wool silk and other animal derived materials Cosmetics and Household Products Chooses cruelty free and vegan products Entertainment and Services Avoids activities and industries that exploit animals such as circuses and zoos Adopting Some Vegan Practices Diet Might include some plant based meals but still consume animal products occasionally Clothing Might opt for synthetic or plant based materials sometimes but still use leather or wool Products May choose cruelty free cosmetics occasionally but not exclusively General Approach Focuses on reducing animal product consumption or usage rather than complete elimination For example someone adopting some vegan practices might enjoy Meatless Mondays opt for cruelty free makeup when possible and choose faux leather jackets over real leather Whether a person chooses to go fully into a vegan lifestyle or simply reduce their animal consumption any of these changes can make a positive impact on not only the world but also their health Health Benefits Adopting a vegan lifestyle can offer numerous health benefits provided the diet is well balanced and includes a variety of nutrient dense foods Heart Health Lower cholesterol levels Reduced risk of heart disease and hypertension Lower blood pressure Weight Management Easier weight control or weight loss Lower body mass index BMI Digestive Health Improved digestion due to high fiber intake Reduced risk of constipation and other digestive issues Blood Sugar Control Improved blood sugar levels and insulin sensitivity Reduced risk of type diabetes Cancer Risk Reduction Lower risk of certain cancers such as colorectal and breast cancer Nutrient Intake Higher intake of essential nutrients like vitamins C and E magnesium folic acid and phytochemicals More antioxidants which can help protect against cell damage Inflammation Reduction Potentially lower levels of inflammation in the body Relief from certain chronic conditions like arthritis Longevity Potential for a longer lifespan due to overall health benefits Kidney Functions Improved kidney function and reduced risk of chronic kidney disease Better Mood and Energy Levels Potential improvement in mood and energy due to better overall health and nutrient intake It s important to note that while a vegan lifestyle can offer these benefits it s essential to plan meals carefully to ensure you re getting all the necessary nutrients Consulting with a healthcare professional or a registered dietitian can help create a well balanced vegan diet that meets your nutritional needs Even adopting a few vegan choices to your diet can have a positive impact on your health and enough of them can make a big difference for the planet Environmental Impact Reducing animal consumption can significantly impact the environment positively reducing the damage done to it so it can survive and thrive Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reduced Emissions Animal agriculture is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions particularly methane from livestock and nitrous oxide from manure By consuming fewer animal products we can reduce these emissions Climate Change Mitigation Lowering greenhouse gas emissions helps combat climate change potentially stabilizing global temperatures Land Use Deforestation Large tracts of forests are cleared to create grazing land and grow feed crops for livestock Reducing animal product consumption can decrease the demand for these lands thereby reducing deforestation Habitat Preservation Preserving forests and other natural habitats protects biodiversity and helps maintain ecosystems Water Use Water Footprint Animal agriculture requires significant amounts of water from growing feed crops to hydrating animals Consuming fewer animal products can reduce the overall water footprint Water Pollution Animal farming operations can pollute waterways with runoff containing manure antibiotics and hormones Reducing animal consumption helps minimize this pollution Energy Use Energy Efficiency Plant based diets generally require less energy to produce than animal products Reducing animal consumption can lead to lower overall energy use in food production Fossil Fuels The production and transportation of animal products often rely heavily on fossil fuels contributing to greenhouse gas emissions Plant based diets can reduce this dependence Soil Health Soil Degradation Intensive animal farming practices can lead to soil degradation through overgrazing and the overuse of chemical fertilizers for feed crops Reducing animal consumption can help mitigate these effects Soil Carbon Sequestration Healthier soil can sequester remove carbon helping to mitigate climate change Biodiversity Species Loss Deforestation and habitat destruction of animal agriculture can lead to the loss of species and biodiversity Reducing demand for animal products helps preserve habitats and protect wildlife Conservation By protecting natural habitats and reducing the expansion of farmland we can support conservation efforts for endangered species Waste Management Animal Waste Livestock produce large amounts of waste which can create significant environmental hazards Reducing animal consumption decreases the production of this waste Resource Efficiency Plant based diets can make more efficient use of resources reducing overall waste Reducing animal consumption even partially can contribute to a healthier planet by lowering greenhouse gas emissions preserving forests conserving water reducing energy use maintaining soil health protecting biodiversity and managing waste more efficiently But going vegan is not just a matter of one s personal health and the environment it is also a matter of ethics Ethical Considerations Choosing a vegan lifestyle can be driven by numerous ethical reasons including animal welfare and factory farms Animal Welfare Reducing Suffering Avoiding animal products helps to prevent the suffering and exploitation of animals in industries such as farming fashion and entertainment Opposition to Factory Farming Factory farms often subject animals to overcrowded unsanitary and inhumane conditions Veganism stands against these practices Environmental Responsibility Sustainability Veganism supports more sustainable farming practices by reducing the demand for resource intensive animal agriculture which often leads to deforestation habitat loss and pollution Climate Change By reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with animal farming veganism helps combat climate change and promote environmental health Health and Well Being Promoting Health By choosing plant based diets individuals can improve their health and reduce the strain on healthcare systems This is an ethical consideration for the collective well being of society Food Security Vegan diets can be more efficient in terms of resource use potentially leading to improved food security and less competition for resources Social Justice Equitable Resource Distribution Animal agriculture often requires vast amounts of water land and crops that could be used more efficiently to feed a larger human population A vegan lifestyle can contribute to more equitable resource distribution Philosophical and Moral Beliefs Respect for Life Some individuals choose veganism based on the belief that all sentient beings have a right to live and not be exploited or harmed for human benefit Ethical Consistency Veganism aligns with values of compassion kindness and justice providing consistency with moral and ethical beliefs Cultural and Religious Reasons Spiritual Beliefs Some cultures and religions advocate for non violence and compassion towards all living beings leading followers to adopt a vegan lifestyle For example many followers of Jainism practice a vegan lifestyle as part of their principle of non violence Ahimsa towards all living beings By choosing a vegan lifestyle individuals can align their actions with their ethical beliefs making a positive impact on animals the environment and society as a whole Tips for Transitioning To Vegan Adopting vegan practices even partially can be a rewarding and impactful journey but it can be an adjustment period So it s a good idea to look up tips that can make it easier Here are some practical tips to help you get started Start Small Meatless Mondays Begin by having one or two plant based days per week This is a manageable way to ease into veganism Swap Ingredients Replace dairy milk with plant based milk like almond soy or oat milk and try meat alternatives like tofu tempeh or seitan Explore New Recipes Experiment Try new recipes and cuisines that are naturally plant based like Mediterranean Indian or Thai dishes Cookbooks and Blogs Use vegan cookbooks and good blogs to find inspiration and delicious recipes Educate Yourself Nutritional Knowledge Learn about essential nutrients and how to get them from plant based sources such as protein from legumes and nuts and iron from leafy greens Documentaries and Books Watch documentaries and read books on veganism to understand the benefits and ethics behind the lifestyle Plan Your Meals Weekly Planning Plan your meals ahead of time to ensure you have all the ingredients you need and to make balanced nutritious choices Batch Cooking Cook in larger quantities and store leftovers for easy plant based meals throughout the week Grocery Shopping Shop the Perimeter Focus on the fresh produce section grains and legumes Avoid heavily processed foods Read Labels Check labels for animal derived ingredients and seek out vegan certified products Find Alternatives Favorite Dishes Veganize your favorite dishes but substituting animal products with plant based alternatives For example use jackfruit as a substitute for pulled pork Snacks and Treats Keep a stock of vegan snacks and treats to satisfy cravings without resorting to non vegan options Community Support Join Groups Connect with local or online vegan communities for support advice and inspiration Dining Out Research vegan friendly restaurants or menu options at your favorite spots Be Patient and Flexible Gradual Changes Understand that it s okay to transition slowly Every small step counts Self Compassion Don t be too hard on yourself if you slip up The goal is progress not perfection Learn About Substitutes Cooking Substitutes Discover substitutes for common non vegan ingredients like eggs use flaxseeds or chia seeds and butter use coconut oil or vegan margarine Diverse Diet Ensure you re getting a diverse diet by incorporating a variety of fruits vegetables grains legumes nuts and seeds Advocate and Educate Spread Awareness Share your journey and knowledge with others to inspire and encourage them Lead by Example Show that adopting vegan practices can be enjoyable and beneficial through your actions Changing your diet isn t easy but it is well worth it There are some misconceptions surrounding veganism that can discourage others but by simply addressing them you ll find that they are anything but fact Addressing the Misconceptions There are multiple concerns and misconceptions about veganism like protein intake taste and expense but with a little information gathering anyone can see that it s all false Let s clear each of these up Protein Intake Misconception Vegans don t get enough protein Reality There are plenty of plant based protein sources that can provide all the essential amino acids These include beans lentils chickpeas tofu tempeh seitan quinoa nuts seeds and even vegetables like spinach and broccoli With a varied diet vegans can easily meet their protein needs Nutrient Deficiencies Misconception Vegans are more prone to nutrient deficiencies Reality With proper planning a vegan diet can provide all essential nutrients Here are some key nutrients to consider Vitamin B Found in fortified foods like plant based milks and cereals or taken as a supplement Iron Plant sources include lentils chickpeas beans tofu quinoa and fortified cereals Pairing these with vitamin C rich foods like citrus foods can enhance absorption Calcium Available in fortified plant milk leafy greens like kale and bok choy almonds and tahini Omega Fatty Acids Found in flaxseeds chia seeds hemp seeds walnuts and algae based supplements Vitamin D Sourced from fortified foods or supplements especially in regions with limited sunlight Protein As mentioned earlier numerous plant based sources can meet protein needs Social Challenges Misconception It s difficult to maintain a vegan diet in social settings Reality While social situations can pose challenges there are ways to navigate them Dining Out Research vegan friendly restaurants or menu options before heading out Many eateries are now offering vegan dishes Social Events Communicate your dietary preferences to hosts in advance Bring a delicious vegan dish to share showcasing how tasty vegan food can be Travel Plan ahead by researching local vegan friendly spots and packing some plant based snacks Family and Friends Be patient and open in discussing your choices Sharing the benefits and deliciousness of vegan meals can foster understanding and acceptance Taste and Variety Misconception Vegan food is bland and limited Reality Vegan cuisine is incredibly diverse and flavorful involving a wide range of global spices Spices herbs and creative cooking techniques can make plant based meals exciting and satisfying For example dishes like vegan curry stir fry and pasta can be bursting with flavor Expense Misconception A vegan diet is more expensive Reality Vegan staples like beans lentils rice pasta and seasonal vegetables are often quite affordable While some specialty vegan products can be pricey a balanced vegan diet can be budget friendly with proper planning Health Misconception A vegan diet is not healthy Reality A well balanced vegan diet can offer numerous health benefits such as lower cholesterol levels reduced risk of chronic diseases improved digestion and better weight management It s essential to focus on whole nutrient dense foods for optimal health By not being deluded by these misconceptions and planning carefully adopting vegan practices or transitioning to a vegan lifestyle can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience It s also important to know that even if you don t go fully vegan it s nothing to feel bad about and you should learn so No Guilt Just Progress Many people can feel overwhelmed or guilty for not going fully vegan and it s important to remind yourself that every positive change counts Acknowledge Small Wins Each plant based meal you choose reduces your environmental footprint and promotes animal welfare Celebrate these small victories without pressuring yourself to be perfect Avoid All or Nothing Thinking There s no one size fits all approach to adopting vegan practices It s okay to take gradual steps and find what works best for you and your lifestyle Focus on Positive Impacts Instead of feeling guilty about not being vegan concentrate on the positive impacts of your choices Remember collective small actions can lead to significant change Be Kind to Yourself Dietary changes can be challenging and it s important to be kind to yourself during this journey Guilt and self criticism can be counterproductive Instead encourage yourself to keep moving forward Support and Community Seek out supportive communities or groups where you can share your experiences challenges and successes Surrounding yourself with like minded individuals can provide motivation and reduce feelings of isolation or guilt Transitioning to a vegan lifestyle or incorporating more vegan practices is a personal journey It s important to recognize and celebrate the progress you ve made rather than focus on what you haven t yet achieved Remember every little bit helps whether it s one vegan meal a week or fully embracing a vegan diet Speaking of meals there are a few that are easy to make and tasty to eat Easy Vegan Recipes If you re worried about going vegan being complicated rest assured it s a lot simpler than you think Here are some simple common and delicious vegan recipes you can try at home Vegan Chickpea Salad Sandwich Ingredients can chickpeas drained and rinsed tablespoons vegan mayo tablespoon Dijon mustard celery stalk finely chopped small red onion finely chopped tablespoon lemon juice Salt and pepper to taste Bread and lettuce leaves for serving Instructions In a bowl mash the chickpeas with a fork until mostly broken down leaving some chunks for texture Add the vegan mayo Dijon mustard celery red onion lemon juice salt and pepper Mix well Serve the chickpea salad on bread as a sandwich or on lettuce leaves as a wrap Vegan Lentil Bolognese Ingredients cup dry lentils rinsed tablespoon olive oil onion finely chopped cloves garlic minced carrot finely chopped can crushed tomatoes tablespoons tomato paste teaspoon dried oregano teaspoon dried basil Salt and pepper to taste Cooked pasta of your choice Instructions Cook the lentils according to the package instructions and set aside In a large pan heat the olive oil over medium heat Add the onion and garlic and saut until softened Add the carrot and celery and cook for a few more minutes Stir in the crushed tomatoes tomato paste oregano basil salt and pepper Simmer for about minutes Add the cooked lentils to the sauce and mix well Simmer for another minutes Serve the lentil bolognese over cooked pasta Vegan Chocolate Avocado Mousse Ingredients ripe avocados pitted and peeled cup unsweetened cocoa powder cup maple syrup cup almond milk or any plant based milk teaspoon vanilla extract Pinch of salt Instructions In a good processor blend the avocados until smooth Add the cocoa powder maple syrup almond milk vanilla extract and salt Blend until creamy and well combined Chill the mousse in the refrigerator for at least minutes before serving Vegan Buddha Bowl Ingredients cup cooked quinoa cup roasted vegetables such as sweet potatoes broccoli and bell peppers cup chickpeas drained and rinsed avocado sliced Handful of mixed greens tablespoons tahini tablespoon lemon juice tablespoon water Salt and pepper to taste Instructions Arrange the cooked quinoa roasted vegetables chickpeas avocado and mixed greens in a bowl In a small bowl whisk together the tahini lemon juice water salt and pepper to make the dressing Drizzle the dressing over the Buddha bowl Vegan Coconut Milk Ice Cream Ingredients cans full fat coconut milk cup maple syrup or agave nectar tablespoon vanilla extract Pinch of salt Optional cup dark chocolate chips dairy free Optional cup chopped nuts Optional cup fresh or frozen berries Instructions Place the cans of coconut in the refrigerator overnight This will help the coconut cream separate from the water Open the chilled coconut milk cans and scoop out the thick coconut cream into a mixing bowl leaving the liquid behind You can save the liquid for smoothies or other recipes Add the maple syrup or agave nectar vanilla extract and a pinch of salt to the coconut cream Use a hand mixer or whisk to blend everything until smooth and creamy Optional If you re adding mix ins like chocolate chips nuts or berries gently fold them into the mixture Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and churn according to the manufacturer s instructions until it reaches a soft serve consistency Transfer the churned ice cream into a freezer safe container cover it and freeze for at least hours or until firm Let the ice cream sit at room temperature for a few minutes to soften before scooping Note If you don t have an ice cream maker follow steps then pour the mixture into a shallow dish and place it in the freezer Stir the mixture every minutes until it reaches the desired consistency These recipes are easy to prepare popular in the vegan community and packed with flavor You can find variations of these recipes from different sources like vegan cookbooks and blogs These recipes will help make becoming a vegan or adopting more vegan practices easier along with the many other resources that can support you on your vegan journey Resources and Support Whether you plan to go fully vegan or adopt some vegan practices the best thing you can have is a variety of resources and support along the way to make the transition easier Here are some great resources to support your vegan journey Websites American Vegan Society Offers a wealth of information on vegan living events and resources The Vegan Society Provides comprehensive guides recipes and support for those transitioning to or maintaining a vegan lifestyle Vegan Foundry A blog that shares reliable information and reviews on various vegan topics VegNews A popular vegan lifestyle magazine with news recipes and product reviews Plant Based News Focuses on the latest news and developments in the plant based community Apps HappyCow A fantastic app for finding vegan and vegetarian restaurants worldwide Food Monster Offers thousands of vegan recipes with meal planning features Day Vegan Kickstart Curated by the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine this app provides recipes and tips for a healthy transition to veganism Dr Greger s Daily Dozen Helps track daily servings of fruit vegetables nuts and other plant based foods Vegan Friendly A UK based app to find vegan products and restaurants Local Groups Meetup Search for vegan meetups in your area to connect with like minded individuals Local Vegan Facebook Groups Many cities have dedicated vegan groups on Facebook where you can find events support and recipes Volunteer at Vegan Cafes or Animal Shelters A great way to meet other vegans and contribute to the community Vegan Potlucks and Gatherings Look for local vegan potlucks or gatherings to share meals and stories with fellow vegans These resources should help you find the support and community you need on your vegan journey It will help make the change to a more vegan lifestyle much easier for you The Vegan Way To be honest I am not a vegan and I don t see myself ever cutting meat and fish out of my diet but I am still finding ways to make vegan adjustments to my life and diet My blog post is not to convince you that everyone should be a vegan it s to help encourage you to try adopting vegan practices inform you about the best way to do it and provide you with the tips and resources needed to make it as easy as possible Just remember be respectful of others dietary choices vegan or not it s your choice to be a vegan and you shouldn t do it because you feel like you have to and don t feel ashamed if you stumble on the journey Do your best even if your best isn t perfect because every step you take on this journey makes a positive impact on the environment the welfare of animals and your health If we could live happy and healthy lives without harming others why wouldn t we Pam Ahern What are your favorite vegan recipes that you would like to share What tips do you want to give to anyone who plans to practice veganism What have been your best resources for transitioning to veganism Please leave your answers in the comment section If you liked this blog post please leave a like subscribe for more posts and share it on your social media to encourage more people to transition to a vegan lifestyle then you can become an Exemplar of Change If you want to learn more about the resources available to help you transition to a vegan lifestyle look at the links below American Vegan Society The Vegan Society Vegan Foundry The Minimalist Vegan Veganuary HappyCow Meetup

At the end of this week and Veganuary Unity Diner will close its doors on February st Another beloved hyped vegan eatery bites the dust Picture this It s Veganuary the annual challenge from that encourages people to go vegan in January with restaurants offering discounts on plant based meals and stores placing more vegan friendly options and sections to choose from Now it s Veganuary there s been fewer if close to no restaurant offers and store adverts for new vegan brand products Aldi s own Lidl s own and instead we re seeing posts that another plant based product is being discontinued and another vegan vegetarian restaurant is closing shop View this post on Instagram A post shared by Unity Diner unitydiner Unity Diner in Aldgate east London is the latest in a series of vegan favourites to announce its closure and in Veganuary of all times From being recommended as a top London vegan restaurant in Vogue Magazine Earthling Ed s Unity Diner ultimately is ending in early closure after six years of business due to the constant problem rising rent costs When I first moved to London in July the capital was brimming with hyped vegan and veggie eating places to choose from It was never a question of where as chains were in multitude but when My friends and I would have weekly catch up dates at the next vegan restaurant on our list to try In fact Vurger co in Shoreditch by the overground was my go to for friends visiting me in London before I did my infamous tours of Brick Lane Rivington Street Commercial Street and the best parts of central east Vegan junk food was on the rise and restaurants exclusively for that purpose were more popular than ever and this was at the beginning of the post pandemic era View this post on Instagram A post shared by Vegan Fast Food VURGER thevurgerco In the three years since countless favourites have dropped off the grid Vurger co in Shoreditch and Brighton Rudy s Vegan Diner and store in Islington then Camden slowly followed Deliciously Ella s restaurant in Mayfair the Croydon and north west London chain of What the Pitta and the Marylebone chain for Wulf Lamb while the Chelsea chain is currently temporarily closed While most vegan eateries are closing due to money shortcomings others went so ghost mode that I had to convince myself it really had existed to begin with Rudy s Dirty Vegan Diner or Rudy s Vegan Diner first closed for renovations in Islington but was never to be seen again Their socials even vanished with their Rudy s Vegan Butcher account left albeit on private It took until recent research to find out there was a fallout with the founders and the company itself see here Old haunts such as Mooshie s in Brick Lane pictured first is a good example of a vegan junk food place which was great on the eyes but not so much on the taste the mixture of sauces were way too overpowering Of course this is also now closed and their socials now focus on human rights politics Meanwhile Rudy s reuben sandwich pictured second and Vurger s burgers shroom fingers and shakes pictured third reigned supreme Maya Kokerov said I want vegan places to stay open but I think vegan options in non vegan restaurants Caf Rouge Meat Liquor Honest Burgers and more from experience are starting to be better quality than actual vegan food at vegan restaurants Even though veganism is declining from mainstream popularity I don t think it s becoming a huge problem but rather that vegans are choosing to eat less processed food and also save money It s true that the booming options a few years ago were solely hinged on vegan junk food our friend group would note that at the time so much so that we were thrilled to discover Wulf Lamb an all vegan and vegetarian actual restaurant No junk food but more cooked meals in smaller portions in true restaurant fashion We tried others such as Stem Glory in the Barbican area but to no avail as the flavours and portions didn t hit the same An exception would be the traditional go to s Mildreds Mallow and Tendril a plant kitchen in Oxford Circus which has the best vegan tiramisu I ve ever had in deep contrast to Unity Diner s And most prominently Jam Delish a black owned vegan caribbean restaurant in Angel Islington they always keep their menu s fresh and out of this world Cecily Grace Morgan said I m really disappointed to see so many vegan places in London close down especially Wulf Lamb in Marylebone and What the Pitta in Camden I think the decrease in popularity of vegan places is probably linked to people s growing wariness of ultra processed foods but I hope we ll see restaurants that focus on plants instead of mock meats like KIN in Fitzrovia thrive The growing consciousness certainly seems to have moved towards being healthy within veganism the plant diet is not solely enough anymore especially now that we know that veganism is here to stay and it s not a passing fancy that the mainstream is taking an interest in it By this I mean back in when vegan products and options were slowly being added to restaurants and stores The transformation in that time alone sent me into disarray I went from fries as a side as my only option in Frankie Benny s and even this was fried in animal fat so it wasn t an option to numerous vegan only eating places as well as vegan menus in mainstream chains Safe to say no one was thinking about whether the food was processed or not back then although we were looking at what it was made from non vegans would hurl this question incessantly Now stepping back into the current climate it s important to preserve the good restaurants we still have to fight against the closures KIN Jam Delish Holy Carrot Dauns and more listed on Happy Cow need us more than ever

Due to the generosity of anonymous donors The Vegetarian Resource Group each year will award in college scholarship money to graduating U S high school students who have promoted veganism in their schools and or communities One award of and six awards of and additional runner up prizes will be given Entries may only be sent by students graduating from high school in SPRING We will accept applications postmarked on or before FEBRUARY Early submission is encouraged Applicants will be judged on having shown compassion courage and a strong commitment to promoting a peaceful world through a vegan diet lifestyle Payment will be made to the student s college U S based only Winners of the scholarships give permission to release their names to the media Applications and essays become property of The Vegetarian Resource Group We may ask finalists for more information Scholarship winners are contacted by e mail or telephone Please look at your e mail If you would like to donate to additional scholarships or internships go to www vrg org donate Applications Please click here to download a PDF of the application However applicants are not required to use an application form A neatly typed document containing the information below will also be accepted as a valid application However applicants are not required to use an application form A neatly typed document containing the information below will also be accepted as a valid application Please send application and attachments to vrg vrg org Scholarship application and your name in subject line or mail to The Vegetarian Resource Group P O Box Baltimore MD If emailing please put your essay in a separate attachment with your first name and last initial A PDF or Word document is preferred but if you send a Google document make sure permission is given so readers can access it For more information call or email vrg vrg org

Planning a successful event requires interest to detail and one of the most considerable elements to take into consideration is the catering menu Food is not simply a need it is an experience that can boost your event from ordinary to phenomenal If you are questioning just how to prepare an event catering menu that accommodates different tastes and nutritional demands you are in the right place Below are important approaches for crafting a memorable catering experience that your visitors will go crazy around long after the occasion finishes First and foremost understanding your target market is important Consider the nature of your event and the choices of your guests A company celebration may need a much more official food selection while a wedding celebration might allow for even more imagination and customization The secret to efficient occasion planning and event catering ideas is understanding that will certainly be attending and what they could take pleasure in Involve with guests in advance when possible to obtain insights into their food choices and any type of dietary restrictions they may have In today s varied culinary landscape suiting nutritional demands in catering is more crucial than ever Numerous guests might have allergies intolerances or specific dietary choices like vegetarianism or veganism Be positive regarding learning these demands by consisting of an RSVP choice that permits visitors to specify their demands This approach not just reveals your visitors that you care yet also allows your catering service to offer a well rounded food selection that every person can appreciate If you fancied this blog post and you want to acquire a lot additional information regarding personal chef kindly head to the article One prominent fad is vegan food selection preparation for events The expanding interest in plant based diet regimens implies that a well balanced vegan menu can delight also one of the most devoted carnivores Include a range of vibrant choices such as baked veggie platters vegan pasta salads and flavorful grain bowls Do not neglect treat vegan delicious chocolate mousse or fruit tarts container be a delightful shock With some creativity and quality components vegan meals can be both pleasing and sophisticated When putting together your catering food selection equilibrium is vital Aim for a selection of tastes and textures to maintain the eating experience amazing Traditional choices like baked chicken or beef tenderloin can be complemented by exciting vegetarian meals and sides making certain that all visitors have something delicious to appreciate Think about incorporating seasonal ingredients for quality and don t forget to include gluten free and nut free choices to better fit dietary requirements in food catering Timing is an additional critical aspect of how to plan a providing food selection properly Depending on your occasion you may pick to offer a buffet layered dishes or even family style dining Buffets permit visitors to pick what they want making it an outstanding alternative for those with particular dietary requirements On the various other hand layered meals supply a more official touch and can be personalized for specific visitors Whichever service design you choose make certain it straightens with the general tone of the event Don t neglect the importance of discussion A wonderfully organized providing spread can substantially boost the environment of your occasion Focus on color texture and arrangement when intending your menu Usage decorative serving meals garnishes and positioning to make the food appearance as appealing as feasible Remember that we eat with our eyes first so culinary discussion can bring an added layer of exhilaration to your event For event hosts catering suggestions extend beyond just the food Think about having actually a marked area for drinks that complements your food selection The best beverages can boost the dining experience and maintain visitors talking and engaged Providing a selection of red wines craft beers or imaginative non alcoholic drinks can offer a well rounded experience Finally do not wait to work together with your event caterer Sharing your vision and being open to their suggestions can result in a more natural and excellent menu An excellent food catering group will certainly have the ability to provide suggestions on trending recipes section sizes and combinations that function well with each other In conclusion planning a catering food selection involves mindful consideration of your target market nutritional requirements in food catering and the overall event ambience Whether you are preparing a business occasion wedding or casual event a thoughtful food selection can make all the difference By following these event preparation and catering tips including a focus on vegan food selection options you can make certain that every visitor leaves completely satisfied and amazed by the cooking experience you have actually developed Happy preparation

Veganism What to Expect During the First Several DaysSwitching to veganism is like embarking on a journey to a foreign land exciting intriguing and sometimes a little overwhelming I remember my first week vividly It wasn t just about cutting out meat dairy and eggs it was about learning a whole new way of thinking about food my body and the world around me If you re considering going vegan or have just taken the plunge you might be wondering What s the first week really like Let me take you through it with all the highs lows surprises and lessons I wish someone had told me Day The Honeymoon PhaseAh the first day of veganism You wake up feeling like a superhero ready to save the planet one meal at a time Your excitement fuels you as you prepare your first fully vegan breakfast For me it was avocado toast sprinkled with chili flakes and a side of black coffee Simple but I felt like a culinary genius What to Expect Excitement and Motivation You re likely feeling inspired thinking about the positive impact you re making on animals the environment and your health Grocery Store Adventures Shopping for vegan food might feel like a scavenger hunt You ll spend a lot of time reading labels which can be eye opening why is there milk powder in everything Pro Tip Stick to the basics at first whole foods like fruits veggies grains and legumes Fancy vegan substitutes can come later Day The Energy BoostBy the second day I noticed something surprising I wasn t dragging myself through the morning like usual My body felt lighter and my energy levels seemed to climb Some people experience this vegan glow early on thanks to the fiber rich nutrient dense foods flooding their system What to Expect Improved Digestion All that fiber from plant based foods starts to work its magic Yes you might be visiting the bathroom a bit more often but trust me it s a good thing A Sense of Accomplishment You ve made it through day one and you re already proving to yourself that you can do this I called my best friend on day two gushing about how much better I felt She joked You re two days in and already a vegan evangelist We laughed but deep down I was proud Day The What Do I Eat MomentBy day three the honeymoon phase might start to wear off If you didn t meal prep or plan ahead you might find yourself staring into the fridge wondering what to eat This was the day I realized just how much I used to rely on cheese as a default ingredient What to Expect Meal Planning Struggles Without a plan you might feel stuck or tempted to fall back on old habits Cravings Begin If you re used to eating a lot of meat or dairy your brain might start craving those familiar flavors Pro Tip Experiment with simple satisfying meals like lentil soup stir fries or pasta with marinara sauce and veggies Day The Detox PhaseLet s talk about the elephant in the room detox As your body adjusts to a plant based diet you might experience a few bumps in the road For me it was bloating and a mild headache This is normal your body is getting used to the influx of fiber and the absence of animal products What to Expect Physical Changes Temporary bloating fatigue or even mild irritability are common Mental Clarity Despite the physical adjustments you might notice your mind feels clearer which is a lovely perk On day four I made a rookie mistake I ate a massive bowl of raw kale salad While it was delicious let s just say my stomach wasn t thrilled I learned the hard way that cooking some veggies makes them easier to digest especially in the beginning Day The Why Am I Doing This QuestionBy the fifth day the initial excitement might be replaced by doubt This was when I started questioning my decision Was I really ready to give up my favorite cheese pizza Could I stick with this long term What to Expect Emotional Wobbles Doubts are natural especially if you re facing criticism or teasing from friends and family Cravings Peak If you re going to cave it s usually around this time Pro Tip Revisit your why Whether it s for the animals the planet or your health reminding yourself of your reasons can reignite your motivation Day The Confidence BoostBy day six something shifted I started feeling more confident in my choices and even tried cooking a more elaborate vegan dish chickpea curry with coconut milk It was a game changer Suddenly I realized how flavorful and satisfying plant based meals could be What to Expect Increased Confidence You re starting to find your groove and maybe even impressing yourself with your cooking skills Social Wins If you ve navigated a dinner with friends or explained your diet to someone you might feel a sense of pride I invited a friend over for dinner on day six She was skeptical about vegan food but ended up loving the curry That small victory made me realize this lifestyle wasn t just for me it could inspire others too Day The Vegan GrooveBy the end of the first week you ll likely notice a few things Your taste buds are starting to adapt You ve discovered some new favorite foods You re feeling lighter more energized and maybe even a little proud of yourself This was the day I truly felt like I could stick with veganism I had my go to meals a better understanding of nutrition and a growing appreciation for this compassionate lifestyle What I Wish I Knew Before StartingNot Everything Vegan Is Healthy Oreos Vegan French fries Vegan But that doesn t mean they re good for you Focus on whole plant based foods for the best results You Don t Have to Be Perfect I stressed so much about accidentally eating something non vegan Spoiler It happens We re all human What matters is your effort and intention You ll Discover Amazing Foods Before going vegan I d never tried nutritional yeast tempeh or jackfruit Now I can t imagine my life without them Tips for SuccessStock Your Kitchen Keep your pantry and fridge filled with staples like beans grains nuts and fresh produce Find Your Support System Join vegan Facebook groups follow plant based influencers or connect with friends who share your journey Be Kind to Yourself This is a big change Celebrate your wins and learn from your mistakes Going vegan isn t just about what you eat it s about aligning your actions with your values It s a journey of discovery growth and compassion And while the first week can feel like a rollercoaster trust me when I say it s worth it By the time you reach the end of that first week you ll have taken a step towards a healthier you a kinder world and a brighter future So if you re thinking about going vegan take it one day at a time and enjoy the ride Switching to veganism is like embarking on a journey to a foreign land exciting intriguing and was originally published in Plantmade on Medium where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story

From varsity co uk lifestyle Edie Castell reflects on the highs and lows of the Veganuary experience The first time I attempted veganism was when I was years old It was the summer of yellow ochre mom jeans and those we should all be feminists tees in other words the perfect environment for half hearted teenage activism I didn t particularly know why I was suddenly avoiding animal products past a general concern for their welfare nor did I have the perseverance to sustain my new diet longer than a few weeks The problem wasn t a lack of passion but rather one fatal flaw that I ve yet to relinquish I am incredibly lazy in the kitchen Especially at university nothing beats the comfort of a bowl of pesto pasta This month however I decided to work against my nature and what better way to do so than to commit to a national movement and an article to hold myself accountable Veganuary for the unacquainted is exactly what you d presume it to be a month long commitment to a vegan diet Since its conception in the movement has only attracted more fanfare it feels like half of my friends have given it a go at one point or another This month I decided to work against my nature and what better way to do so than to commit to Veganuary Natasha Larsen for Varsity There s no arguing that the case for a vegan diet is compelling Not only has it been linked to certain health benefits like a lower blood pressure and cholesterol but cutting out meat has a genuine environmental impact It s common knowledge that a reduction in our meat intake would lead to a better carbon footprint These factors considered I spent the better part of my New Year s Eve excitedly sharing my new endeavour to go into completely plant based As the new year dawned I was admittedly over confident about the ease with which I would take to this shift in my diet As a passionate butter hater and plant milk connoisseur I felt like I was already halfway to veganism What I hadn t accounted for was waking up on New Year s Day exhausted mildly hungover in the midst of a rain storm My early morning supermarket plans foiled I opted to make do with what I could find in my cupboards A simple tomato and lentil pasta seemed like my easiest bet and the dish came together smoothly However after struggling through half a bowl of tomato pasta sans cheese I realised it was lacking the umami taste I craved Going vegan I was quick to note eliminated many of my go to embellishments for simple meals Gone were the days where I could just chuck a load of cheddar over a mediocre dish and call it a day All hope was not lost however and to prevent you from succumbing to a similar fate I have compiled a tried and true list of easy food embellishments Absolutely anything pickled or fermented gherkins olives onions jalapenos kimchi take your pick Seeds and nuts peanuts and sesame seeds were wins for me though I can also envision cashews or pistachios complimenting a pasta dish or curry Crunchy veg Finely chopping up some celery chillies or bell peppers allows for a more diverse array of textures Liberal seasoning even if you fail to venture past salt and pepper being slightly more generous with your food to seasoning ratio can make all the difference It didn t take too long to adjust more fully to my new lifestyle achieved by sitting down and writing out a proper meal plan Among the highlights of my meals were colourful finely chopped salads and even ready meal vegan curries from the supermarket My attempt at veganism also gave me a chance to finally settle my long held grudge against tofu In the past I have been victim to it at its least seasoned and it took accepting a couple hours of marination to truly obtain the flavour I d been searching for I let the cubes sit in a mix of sriracha and tahini before popping them in the oven at degrees celsius for half an hour My biggest win was my discovery that hummus is in fact vegan which widened the potential for out of meal time snacking Eating out whilst vegan can be in better situations limiting and at worst entirely fruitless Whilst the pubs restaurant and markets of London and indeed Cambridge boast a plethora of vegan options a local pub in Grays lacked the same menu The sole vegan option a faux chicken burger counterintuitively served with a saucer of mayo was clearly not a bestseller There s no meat in that You know that right the waitress clarified in a tone that suggested I was making a grave error with my order She wouldn t have been all that incorrect it was by no means fine dining I can appreciate a pack of Linda McCartney veggie sausages with the best of them but I ve found over the course of this experience that meat mock ups tend to pale in comparison to whole foods that just so happen to be vegan In my eyes a portobello mushroom serves as a much better burger filling than a Quorn patty So will I continue my veganism into February The jury is still out on that one whilst I ve enjoyed the challenge of straying from my comfort zone with my cooking I haven t been sold on going entirely plant based just yet However whatever I end up deciding this experience has certainly pushed me to be more mindful about what I consume Putting extra consideration into the food I choose to buy and cook has shifted eating into a more deliberate practice rather than just a functional one I anticipate many trips to Mill Road the heart of vegan cuisine this Lent term https www varsity co uk lifestyle

A new year feels like a fresh start an opportunity to make choices that reflect who we want to be This January I m inviting you to join me in making one of the most impactful choices you can going vegan Whether you re looking to improve your health reduce your environmental impact or show compassion for animals going vegan this month is a great way to start Why Go Vegan You might be wondering Why go vegan The answer is simple veganism can transform your health reduce your carbon footprint and help animals By switching to a plant based lifestyle you re making a positive impact on the environment animal rights and your health and well being Plus it s easier than ever to enjoy delicious healthy and cruelty free meals How to Start Your Vegan Journey This January I understand that switching to a vegan lifestyle can feel overwhelming So how do you get started Here are a few simple steps to help you take the plunge Try Plant Based Meals Start with easy and tasty dishes like veggie stir fries pasta with dairy free pesto or plant based burgers Substitute Dairy and Meat There are many alternatives available whether it s oat milk in your coffee or a hearty bean salad for lunch Making the switch is easier than ever Tap Into Resources and Community Support There are cookbooks blogs and apps to guide you along the way Be sure to check out the list at the end for helpful tools Why Veganuary Is the Perfect Time to Go Vegan That brings me to Veganuary a global campaign that encourages people to try a plant based lifestyle for the month of January It s a wonderful chance to experiment with new foods explore the joys of plant based eating and see how you feel after a month of avoiding animal products Whether you re motivated by reducing your environmental impact improving your health or standing up for animal rights Veganuary is the perfect time to explore veganism Sharing My Personal Journey Aligning Actions with Values I was a vegetarian for years since childhood believing that I was doing my part for animals the planet and my health But a few years ago I learned something that shifted my perspective I discovered the harsh realities of the dairy industry I didn t realize how cruel dairy production could be Female cows are repeatedly impregnated for milk production and their newborn calves are taken away almost immediately after birth The heartbreak of this knowledge led me to stop drinking milk and eating dairy I transitioned to a vegan lifestyle It wasn t always easy but my commitment grew stronger and when my husband joined me it became even easier Becoming vegan wasn t just about food it was about aligning my actions with my values How Can You Make a Difference If you re ready to make a positive change in your life now is the perfect time Whether you go fully vegan or simply reduce your animal product intake every small change counts Let s make a lasting impact with compassionate choices If you re ready to try veganism or learn more drop a comment below let s support each other on this journey Share your experiences ask questions and know that you re part of a supportive vegan community cheering you on Ready to start your vegan journey Subscribe to my website for more tips recipes and resources to help you along the way Resources to Help You on Your Vegan Journey Vegan Starter Kit Veganuary A free resource to get you started with tips recipes and meal plans https veganuary com Plant Based Recipe Websites Minimalist Baker Simple and delicious plant based recipes https minimalistbaker com Forks Over Knives Healthy whole food plant based recipes https www forksoverknives com Apps HappyCow Find vegan friendly restaurants stores and cafes near you https www happycow net Minute Vegan Quick and easy vegan meal ideas https www minutvegan com Documentaries What the Health A documentary on how diet affects health and the environment https www whatthehealthfilm com Cowspiracy A film exploring the environmental impact of animal agriculture https www cowspiracy com This year let s make a lasting impact with compassionate choices If you re ready to try veganism or learn more check out these resources or drop a comment below let s support each other on this journey Share your experiences ask questions and be part of a vegan community cheering you on Let s make this year more compassionate go vegan for yourself The post New Year New You Why Go Vegan and How to Make Compassionate Choices appeared first on Suzana Gartner
